story:
Hey there, I'm Megan, otherwise known as Wayfaring Seamstress. When times are normal and COVID-free, my friends and I are actors and costumers, putting on shows or attending cosplay conventions. But things these days are a little more complicated, and we're finding new ways to work together to express our love of the arts and the collaboration that goes with it. 

Enter this project. I have photogenic actor and dancer friends, know a photographer and makeup artist, and we all love the magic of Disney. We needed something to do, and we decided to make magic.

And now, enter you. Making costumes for ten people, especially elaborate ones based on historical designs or fairy tale dreams, is not a cheap endeavor. While, as the seamstress, I'm attempting to do this as much as I can out of my own budgeting and resources, I'm finding that I NEED a little help. Your help. So here's the plan:

For the past several months, I've been designing costumes based not only one the characters, but the people who will be wearing them. While not all the designs have been finalized, I'll be updating this page with them as I do. My facebook page and twitter are also a great source of information for day to day updates on the project, including candids, fabric swatches, silliness with the models, and more, and both can be found here:

https://www.facebook.com/WayfaringSeamstress

https://twitter.com/WayfaringSeams

 

Ariel and Eric

For Prince Eric, I wanted to stay true to his action and adventure sailor persona, without completely loosing his original design. And his original design is... Well, let's just say open V-necks and cummborbunds aren't exactly fashion norms. But I searched through some reference images and found that the dress uniform of the French Foreign Legion actually wears cummborbunds. This inspiration is exactly what I needed. 

For Ariel, I went through a few trials, but I finally decided to redesign the dress she wears the briefest amount in the film, during her final transformation into a human. I wanted something that looked like rippling waves along the beach- like seafoam, almost like a play on the original fairy tale in which mermaids are doomed to turn into it, and also based on the lyrics from the Broadway musical-only song "Her Voice" referring to a girl "who's like the glimmer of the sunlight on the sea"

 

Phillip and Aurora

This inspiration for Aurora's gown came entirely from a lucky find in a fabric store- a beautiful piece of embroidered mesh covered in gold trimmed pink roses with lovely dark, dark teal blue leaves and vines. The combination of the two colors of her dress in one struck me, and I began planning in my head immediately.

With Phillip, well, I've LOVED the recent redesigns the Disney Parks have done with the character, particularly in their Festival of Fantasy Parade in which he fights an actual, clockwork firebreathing dragon. It was simply a matter of comparing my favorite parts of each design and then matching the colors to fit Aurora.

 

Belle and the Beast

Belle deserves a special spotlight for how much of an alteration it is. The robe a la française is one of my favorite historical dress styles, and thankfully, the lovely lady playing Belle agrees. I couldn't decide how to approach the color, because the big layers of yellow just... wasn't speaking to me. We found a similarly floral printed dress, and things just began to click from there. While Belle is elegant, she is also a more simplistic beauty than some of her other princess counterpoints, and this dress is meant to reflect that.

The Beast is still a work in progress, but I figured you might enjoy seeing him none-the-less. As much as I LOVE 18th century women's clothing, the men's clothes in that era... aren't my favorite. But I'm slowly piecing together something I can live with. This piece is definitely one of the more collaborative ones, requiring the skills of myself, and sculptor, and a makeup artist to fully realize. It's difficult, and also probably the one I'm most excited to see finished.

 

Rapunzel and Flynn Rider

 

Rapunzel's costume is being designed by the lovely lady wearing her, Amy. She says that the bottom of the bodice is meant to invoke the sun design that is the symbol of the kingdom of Corona and plans on doing more of a long, traditionally fairy tale braid instead of the loose hair from the movie. You can find her on Instagram here for more of her work -https://www.instagram.com/amyhotovchin/

Of course, we all know that Flynn Rider is just an alias for Eugene Fitzherbert, and it's one of Eugene's outfits that I got the idea for this costume from. I was stuck for a while because let's face it, as far as designs for Disney men go, Flynn Rider is close to perfect, and changing or improving upon that felt like an impossible task. Thankfully, the Tangled Adventures animated series came to my rescue, and after borrow some design elements from one of his outfits there and tweaking the color scheme with help from Amy, we came up with this. You're all going to swoon when you see this boy smolder in this outfit, I guarantee it.

 

Aladdin and Jasmine

 

While we don't have designs finalized for these two yet, I can give you some hints- my good friend Namitha is taking the lead, wanting to take her first hand knowledge of modern Indian fashion to create something truly unique for the two characters. She and I will be working together on Aladdin while she designs something for Jasmine which she'll be wearing herself. As someone with very little experience in that area, I'm super excited to learn more, and to create a look for two characters that isn't so heavily influenced by, well... white fashion designers, lol.  

UPDATE!!

We've been working hard, and gotten a design for Aladdin figured out. 

 

 

We want to reward you for helping us out! And while we don't have much, we do have a few little things that we think you'll love. So please check the side of this page for more information on the perks and rewards that we have for you. If Stretch Goals are made, more rewards might be added in the future. 

And no matter what you do to help us, whether it's spreading the word, just donating some spare change, or helping out with a big contribution, you're going to get to see an amazing final product. Our photographer, Firefly Photography, will be posting images free for all to see online on facebook and their website. 

https://www.facebook.com/fireflyphotoco

https://fireflyphotographyco.mypixieset.com/

 

Here are a couple examples of their previous work with these same actors and models:

 

For us, the biggest reward will be getting to pursue our craft and build pieces for our portfolios, without going bankrupt in the process. Things right now are... well, it's almost beyond words how bad they are for stage performers, costumers, crews, etc. especially those of us involved in small local and community theaters. We miss doing what we love, and this helps us do just a small bit of that, while also preparing for a future when we can hopefully join together as a community and collaborate again. For helping us with that, even with just a share or a single dollar donation, we are extremely grateful.

 

 

While our initial goal of $500 will help a lot with funding this project, meeting further goals will help us turn it into something that seems, well, out of a fairy tale dream. Here's what we can do with each met goal:

  • Initial goal $500 - 1/3 of the fabric costs will be covered
  • First stretch goal $750 - Further covers material costs, plus gives us room in the budget to splurge on some props
  • Second stretch goal $1000 - More than half the material costs, and even more props!
  • Third stretch goal $1500 - Fabric costs are completely covered!
  • Fourth stretch goal $2000 - Not only will material costs be covered and fun props and photoshoot additions added, but we will also be able to pay the participants a small stipend. Also, I will cry. Like, a lot. 

 

Obviously, not everyone can help in the form of money, and that's okay. We really appreciate help in any form, ESPECIALLY when it comes to getting the word out. Please share our campaign where you can- there are links for Facebook and Twitter specifically through Indiegogo, and as well as a link you can copy. You're helping make magic with every share.

 

 

I and the rest of the crew cannot thank you enough for your contribution to this project. Especially in these time, when theater and entertainment industries are struggling so much, your help means so much to us. It's a whole new world, and we're trying to find our way in it. Thank you, truly.
story_txt:
Hey there, I'm Megan, otherwise known as Wayfaring Seamstress. When times are normal and COVID-free, my friends and I are actors and costumers, putting on shows or attending cosplay conventions. But things these days are a little more complicated, and we're finding new ways to work together to express our love of the arts and the collaboration that goes with it. 
Enter this project. I have photogenic actor and dancer friends, know a photographer and makeup artist, and we all love the magic of Disney. We needed something to do, and we decided to make magic.
And now, enter you. Making costumes for ten people, especially elaborate ones based on historical designs or fairy tale dreams, is not a cheap endeavor. While, as the seamstress, I'm attempting to do this as much as I can out of my own budgeting and resources, I'm finding that I NEED a little help. Your help. So here's the plan:


For the past several months, I've been designing costumes based not only one the characters, but the people who will be wearing them. While not all the designs have been finalized, I'll be updating this page with them as I do. My facebook page and twitter are also a great source of information for day to day updates on the project, including candids, fabric swatches, silliness with the models, and more, and both can be found here:
https://www.facebook.com/WayfaringSeamstress
https://twitter.com/WayfaringSeams
 
Ariel and Eric

For Prince Eric, I wanted to stay true to his action and adventure sailor persona, without completely loosing his original design. And his original design is... Well, let's just say open V-necks and cummborbunds aren't exactly fashion norms. But I searched through some reference images and found that the dress uniform of the French Foreign Legion actually wears cummborbunds. This inspiration is exactly what I needed. 
For Ariel, I went through a few trials, but I finally decided to redesign the dress she wears the briefest amount in the film, during her final transformation into a human. I wanted something that looked like rippling waves along the beach- like seafoam, almost like a play on the original fairy tale in which mermaids are doomed to turn into it, and also based on the lyrics from the Broadway musical-only song "Her Voice" referring to a girl "who's like the glimmer of the sunlight on the sea"
 
Phillip and Aurora

This inspiration for Aurora's gown came entirely from a lucky find in a fabric store- a beautiful piece of embroidered mesh covered in gold trimmed pink roses with lovely dark, dark teal blue leaves and vines. The combination of the two colors of her dress in one struck me, and I began planning in my head immediately.
With Phillip, well, I've LOVED the recent redesigns the Disney Parks have done with the character, particularly in their Festival of Fantasy Parade in which he fights an actual, clockwork firebreathing dragon. It was simply a matter of comparing my favorite parts of each design and then matching the colors to fit Aurora.
 
Belle and the Beast

Belle deserves a special spotlight for how much of an alteration it is. The robe a la française is one of my favorite historical dress styles, and thankfully, the lovely lady playing Belle agrees. I couldn't decide how to approach the color, because the big layers of yellow just... wasn't speaking to me. We found a similarly floral printed dress, and things just began to click from there. While Belle is elegant, she is also a more simplistic beauty than some of her other princess counterpoints, and this dress is meant to reflect that.

The Beast is still a work in progress, but I figured you might enjoy seeing him none-the-less. As much as I LOVE 18th century women's clothing, the men's clothes in that era... aren't my favorite. But I'm slowly piecing together something I can live with. This piece is definitely one of the more collaborative ones, requiring the skills of myself, and sculptor, and a makeup artist to fully realize. It's difficult, and also probably the one I'm most excited to see finished.
 
Rapunzel and Flynn Rider

 
Rapunzel's costume is being designed by the lovely lady wearing her, Amy. She says that the bottom of the bodice is meant to invoke the sun design that is the symbol of the kingdom of Corona and plans on doing more of a long, traditionally fairy tale braid instead of the loose hair from the movie. You can find her on Instagram here for more of her work -https://www.instagram.com/amyhotovchin/
Of course, we all know that Flynn Rider is just an alias for Eugene Fitzherbert, and it's one of Eugene's outfits that I got the idea for this costume from. I was stuck for a while because let's face it, as far as designs for Disney men go, Flynn Rider is close to perfect, and changing or improving upon that felt like an impossible task. Thankfully, the Tangled Adventures animated series came to my rescue, and after borrow some design elements from one of his outfits there and tweaking the color scheme with help from Amy, we came up with this. You're all going to swoon when you see this boy smolder in this outfit, I guarantee it.
 
Aladdin and Jasmine
 
While we don't have designs finalized for these two yet, I can give you some hints- my good friend Namitha is taking the lead, wanting to take her first hand knowledge of modern Indian fashion to create something truly unique for the two characters. She and I will be working together on Aladdin while she designs something for Jasmine which she'll be wearing herself. As someone with very little experience in that area, I'm super excited to learn more, and to create a look for two characters that isn't so heavily influenced by, well... white fashion designers, lol.  
UPDATE!!
We've been working hard, and gotten a design for Aladdin figured out. 

 
 


We want to reward you for helping us out! And while we don't have much, we do have a few little things that we think you'll love. So please check the side of this page for more information on the perks and rewards that we have for you. If Stretch Goals are made, more rewards might be added in the future. 
And no matter what you do to help us, whether it's spreading the word, just donating some spare change, or helping out with a big contribution, you're going to get to see an amazing final product. Our photographer, Firefly Photography, will be posting images free for all to see online on facebook and their website. 
https://www.facebook.com/fireflyphotoco
https://fireflyphotographyco.mypixieset.com/
 
Here are a couple examples of their previous work with these same actors and models:


 
For us, the biggest reward will be getting to pursue our craft and build pieces for our portfolios, without going bankrupt in the process. Things right now are... well, it's almost beyond words how bad they are for stage performers, costumers, crews, etc. especially those of us involved in small local and community theaters. We miss doing what we love, and this helps us do just a small bit of that, while also preparing for a future when we can hopefully join together as a community and collaborate again. For helping us with that, even with just a share or a single dollar donation, we are extremely grateful.
 


 
While our initial goal of $500 will help a lot with funding this project, meeting further goals will help us turn it into something that seems, well, out of a fairy tale dream. Here's what we can do with each met goal:

Initial goal $500 - 1/3 of the fabric costs will be covered
First stretch goal $750 - Further covers material costs, plus gives us room in the budget to splurge on some props
Second stretch goal $1000 - More than half the material costs, and even more props!
Third stretch goal $1500 - Fabric costs are completely covered!
Fourth stretch goal $2000 - Not only will material costs be covered and fun props and photoshoot additions added, but we will also be able to pay the participants a small stipend. Also, I will cry. Like, a lot. 


 

Obviously, not everyone can help in the form of money, and that's okay. We really appreciate help in any form, ESPECIALLY when it comes to getting the word out. Please share our campaign where you can- there are links for Facebook and Twitter specifically through Indiegogo, and as well as a link you can copy. You're helping make magic with every share.
 
 
I and the rest of the crew cannot thank you enough for your contribution to this project. Especially in these time, when theater and entertainment industries are struggling so much, your help means so much to us. It's a whole new world, and we're trying to find our way in it. Thank you, truly.

story:
Hi everyone! My name is David Salazar. Some of you might know me as Poolboy!  I am a longtime burner that was raised in Austin, Texas and now resides in New Orleans, Louisiana.

I am a metal artist that has produced art for Burning Flipside and Burning Man for over 9 years.

I was commissioned to come up with a performance pole for my Burning Man theme camp The Swamp Fuckits, and Octahera is what came out of my brain. It took a village to make her into reality and I am super proud of her. I would love to bring her to my home burn, Burning Flipside 2017, and share her with my original burn family. She's a super fun and beautiful interactive art sculpture!

We are looking for $1500.00 to get her ready and transport her to Apache Pass for the event! 

Some of that money will also go to building a stage that surrounds the diamond and covers her support structure. Its also more room to interact and live your fantasy as you perform with and on her!

Another portion of the proceeds will go to fulfilling the incentives we are offering in thanks for your donations. 

If we do not reach our goal we will be using the money we have received to help us get her there regardless!

Octahedra is a super fun super interactive Diamond-shaped spinning dance pole. She is surrounded by a fully welded and bolted diamond outer shell that is claimable. (4 person max)

If we do meet our goal we will be getting her there regardless but at great expense to ourselves.

Please donate what you can and please help us by sharing this campaign far and wide!

 

Thank you,

David aka, poolboy

 

<3

)'(

story:
We are building a network that brings people together. And you can be part of it.

Itinerant Assembly is a project informed by an understanding that today nomadic modes of living and working, whether forced or desired, are ubiquitous in global cities like London. This includes both the displacement of people due to rapid urban redevelopment and hyper-mobile lifestyles, where digital technology allows people to live and work on the move, forming networked and mobile communities of people across different countries and time zones.

The Itinerant Assembly project is a programme of new artist commissions that explore these concerns, each of which is documented through graphic-designed how-to manuals which will be housed on the project's digital platform. The platform acts as a growing body of research throughout the project which will culminate in an immersive installation by artist collective (play)ground-less and a live online conversation broadcast to three sites in London: Gasworks, Second Home and Green Rooms.

Itinerant Assembly is co-curated by Alice White, Chloe Hodge, Hannah Zafiropoulos, Rosie Hermon,Tiffany Leung and Xiaoyi Nie, a collective of emerging curators interested in experimental methods of engaging people in urgent conversations.

We invite you to join us and support the production of these ambitious and exciting events:

International artist collective (play)ground-less live and work across 3 time zones. As part of the Itinerant Assembly project, (play)ground-less will create a groundbreaking virtual environment - a space in which they can meet and collaborate in virtual reality from their different locations. Within an immersive installation at Gasworks, they invite people to enter their virtual world, as they create collaborative digital artworks in real time.

(play)ground-less, (2015)

Using this installation as a stage, the final event revolves around a live conversation taking place on a digital Hackpad. This is a web-based collaborative real-time text editor, which will be simultaneously streamed to three sites. This will create an event that unfolds across London through performative interventions as artists interact with this conversation at Gasworks, Second Home and Green Rooms.

The live conversation will include invited international participants from across Europe, South America and Asia, drawing together questions that have arisen through research generated by the wider Itinerant Assembly project. It will be broadcast online via thisistomorrow, contemporary art magazine and archive of innovative and culturally significant exhibitions.

These events form the heart of the Itinerant Assembly community - which is created through temporary moments, meetings of people and productive conversations. As an itinerant community its members are a dislocated network, formed through the relations between people who are concerned with the questions of the project. The community of the project is everyone we have worked with, artists, other collaborators, supporters and friends.
Through supporting this project we are inviting you to become a member of the Itinerant Assembly.

​A few of our rewards: Itinerant Assembly tote bag and a limited edition digital print by international artist collective (play)ground-less

The money raised will go to support play(ground)-less in the production of their project. The exhibition will be the first large-scale exhibition by the collective, enabling them to work with an exciting new medium. Part of the funds raised will support the development of this technology in collaboration with Werkflow Ltd. The funds will go directly to producing an artwork which will break new ground in its experimental use of Virtual Reality, pushing the boundaries of what is possible to lead the way both artistically and technologically.

Your contribution will also support the production of the final Hackpad event, the culmination of the Itinerant Assembly project, through funding the participation of international participants in the conversation and performance-based interventions by commissioned artists.

We invite you to help us raise our target of £1500, and to join the community here, online and at the events, which will take place at Gasworks, Second Home and Green Rooms between 11th - 18th May 2016. Follow us on social media to learn more about the project!

Thank you very much for your support!

story:
GOmez ARTS Non-Profit is now 501c3 official and we are looking forward to creating and implementing art programs for underserved communities...

With this newly restructured move, we could use your help to achieve our goals for 2019. 

Our focus is to create Art Programs for Seniors and Veterans, Art Therapy Programs for Children and Adults, and to increase our Community outreach while also creating a fully-optimized website that provides additional resources and information to vested communities. The New Year holds much promise, but it will also present many challenges if we are to successfully implement our creative workshops and art classes for people of all ages. 

With your help our goal to raise $4000 before December 15, 2018 is achievable, and no amount is too small! All donations are tax deductible and...

Donations of $50 or more will receive a GOmez ARTS hand-screened tee- shirt as a gift of thanks from us.

Donations of $100 or more will receive a GOmez ARTS sweatshirt.

Donations of $500 or more will receive A custom tee, a sweatshirt and a piece of artwork made by one of our creative workshops students!

This would be a great opportunity to get your tax deductions for the 2018 tax year AND give both adults and children an opportunity to heal and thrive through art. 

In closing, myself, along with co-founders Lauren Freeman and Ned Harris, are so thankful to ALL OF YOU for your time and consideration and especially for you continued love and support. We are so grateful!

story:
Nails & Beauty

THE FILM

Awkward teen Lucy escapes dull suburbia and archaic gender constraints when she’s thrown into the absurd world of the buff and brilliant builder Louisa at ‘Nails & Beauty’. This is the alternative beauty salon where Louisa and her assistants perform unconventional beauty makeover treatments involving power tools, cement baths, and unique builders-tea ‘hot-stone’ therapies. Through a revelatory transformation à la Louisa, Lucy discovers a new mode of womanhood and a space where she belongs.

Nails & Beauty seeks to subvert gender expression by playfully re-presenting the pop-culture makeover trope featured in ‘girly’ teen films such as Clueless, The Princess Diaries and Mean Girls.

The film script has been developed through BFI Network's Short Film development programme. We're extremely pleased to have secured part funding for this film's production, are now seeking the remainder for our scheduled 3-day shoot in Margate in May 2021.

YOUR CONTRIBUTION

Your contribution will be used to pay cast, crew members and creative collaborators...(and maybe even..me? lololol just kidding!!) Outlandish costumes, absurd props and surreal sets are central to this films concept. Your support will go towards funding the creation of artwork for our film:

  • A bespoke hi-vis tuxedo suit and ball gown, created by our costume maker.
  • A bath filled with 'cement', created by our carpenter and set builder extraordinaire. This prop requires time, work and experimentation. The cement needs to churn, it needs to be opaque, and it needs to look chunky...could it be porridge? Only experimentation will tell.
  • Transforming local workshop 'Grandad's Workshop' into a magical, surreal space that sits somewhere in between carpentry workshop and beauty salon.

Your support means that we can deliver the highest quality film possible. Importantly, this will increase our chances of achieving film festival screenings, which will lead to future opportunities by enabling us to: 

  • Develop our profiles as artists.
  • Expand our networks by engaging with the communities that film festivals foster.
  • Build strong collaborative relationships, making future work opportunities possible.

PRINTS

I've made a wee range of colourful, thematic prints available to purchase / send to you as thank for your support <3 

 

ABOUT MOI

I'm a visual artist, a 2017 BA graduate of the Slade School of Fine Art and 2019 Open School East alumnus. Since graduating I've focused on creating films because I love the creative collaboration that filmmaking is.  My absurd handmade props and costumes are the genesis from which my passion for filmmaking grew. In Nails & Beauty, these strands of my practice converge with the work of admirable collaborators in an uplifting, comedic, experimental film that creatively explores themes of self-discovery and transformation.

View work at www.rhonafoster.com

 

Rhona has recently exhibited work at South London Gallery, EMBASSY Gallery (Edinburgh), Bow Arts’ Visions in the Nunnery (London), SET (London), and The Newbridge Project (Newcastle). Her films have shown at London Short Film Festival, Aesthetica Short Film Festival, Bolton and Sunderland Film Festivals.

Rhona's work has been selected for Bloomberg New Contemporaries 2018 and BBC Scotland & LUX: Now & Next Artist's Film Commissions 2019. In 2019 she was awarded BFI network funding to create the short film ‘Me & My Friends’.

story:
Thanks to everyone who donated, we appreciate your kind support and encourage others to donate as the campaign has few days left till it wraps up. 

 

INEXTINGUISHABLE SUNS TOUR SPRING 2019

 

At first glance you may be mistaken into thinking the two images below are a photograph, in fact they are hand drawn pencil artwork crafted by me.

Immediately you are drawn in closer to the image to try and figure out if it’s a drawing or a photograph trying to capture the glisten of the graphite in the light, it is then that you are drawn in by the finite details... the wrinkles on the elderly lady's face or the stray white hairs individually defined on my grandfathers drawing, and its upon looking at the finite detail that you are transported to the time and place that tells the plight of the Palestinian cause.

Allow me to introduce myself... I'm Adam Shehada a self taught hyper realistic pencil artist living under occupation in Gaza, Palestine.

Hyper realistic pencil and charcoal drawings from my debut collection Inextinguishable Suns

 

 

 

 

My story

 

As an artist from Gaza with a dream, I grew up not only witnessing but living the daily suffering caused by the occupation

The scenes and smell of dust filing the house choking us as the walls were being destroyed , the screams of mom trying to stop Israeli bulldozers before they kill us, that's only glimpse of what my memory could recall at the age of 11.

The scene of death I saw that night and every night during the wars Gaza has been through still flash in my head with the fall of every new martyr or injured .

My dream was to become an artist and animator who creates cartoons for children, I grew up and that dream was replaced with a much deeper one which is to advocate the rights of the oppressed children in the world through my talent

I have spent many years teaching myself and refining my artistic skills, until I was able to earn the respect of some important local and international artists.

And for this, I want to introduce you to my debut hyper realistic art collection titled ' Inextinguishable Suns', after years of hard work and dedication

Today I'm announcing the launch of my UK tour 2019, the purpose of it is to highlight 'in a very new artistic style' the suffering of children in Palestine in particular and their peers around the globe who are subjected to similar injustice in general.

 

I explore the human values which must be given to these children who are the hope of the future in the world

I'm hoping to be able to achieve this dream of mine, and that could only happen if you guys decide to help me. Any amount/contribution would make a difference, no matter how small it is, it will be the pebble that build the mountain.

I completely understand if you are not able to donate, you can share this post/campaign with your friends.

 

 

Who is Adam Shehada?

I was born in 1991 in Gaza, Palestine .Since a very young age I have developed a passion for art and have spent much of my life pursuing this passion and refining my talents.

I have participated in many local art activities, seminars, TV and radio interviews as well as holding hyper realism workshops of low registration fees to help other local artist further their artistic skills.

I have always admired the artwork of the leading hyper realism artists internationally and as hyper realism is relatively new in Gaza the only way for me to develop my skills (as there were no hyper realism art classes held in Gaza at the time) was to look closely at the detail in the artworks of artists such as Kelvin Okafor, Paul Cadden, Gotfried Henlwen and Samantha Messias and through a process of trial and error I tried to recapture their methods. Over the years I have developed a friendship with these artists, who have kindly offered support and advice with regards to how to develop my talents.

In May 2018 I participated in an exhibition in Ramallah at Zawyeh gallery. My artwork was displayed alongside the art of legendary Palestinian artists such as Suleiman Mansour but sadly due to the restrictions on travel I wasn't able to attend the exhibition.

Despite my noticeable talent, my artworks never bypassed the borders of Palestine due to the complications and restrictions imposed by the occupation; therefore this opportunity to exhibit my collection in the UK seems to come just in the right time.  

Me standing next to my artwork is such a perfect chance for my art t get the recognition it deserves and to personally tell the story behind each artwork.

We believe that the world should see the best of Palestinian talents that live under occupation.

 

Artist of The Month on 'This Week In Palestine' Magazine 2018'

 

 

 

The significance of 'Inextinguishable Suns' Tour

 

The significance of this creative tour doesn’t only lie in highlighting the suffering of oppressed in Palestine but also everyone who lacks the basic human rights around the world such as in Syria, Yemen, Africa, Burma and many other places which suffered from oppression and persecution for a very long time.

'Inextinguishable Suns' is the first hyper realistic collection crafted by a Palestinian artist that narrates the hardships of the innocent people in Palestine especially children who are the most affected by war.

To produce these drawings it took me hundreds or even thousands of working hours, dedication, patience and perseverance. What made it even harder was the severe circumstances that I was going through during the drawing process such as the consistent bombardment, the harsh power rationing and the fear and concern due to the unstable political and economical situation in Gaza.

 

THE TOUR

 

 

 

The significance of exhibiting in the UK parliaments:

 

1.      I will be the first Palestinian artist to exhibit my art in the UK parliaments.

2.      The parliaments are considered to be the decision making centers that shape countries policies. Showcasing the narrative of the children and people who yearn for justice and freedom in a creative way will have a great impact on those decision makers, the people in the UK and even people from around the world who are going to see and hear about this event on the news.

3.      The impact is going to be reflected on the people living in Gaza and Palestine, it will not only attract support towards the cause but also it will have a special effect on artists living there by giving them hope that they can achieve their dreams despite all odds.

4. Having a chance to display my artwork in parliament will afford the people of the UK an opportunity to experience my artwork in the mother of parliaments, and to give me a platform to present my work to parliamentarians from both houses and the many staff who work in the parliament, is an opportunity that simply cannot be missed.

 

 

Invitations which are gonna be activated upon my arrival to the UK:

When I found out that I was not able to meet the financial requirements to come to the UK and hold these important exhibitions below, I felt really disheartened, and since then me and my dear friend Farzana have been expanding our efforts in arranging more venues for the tour, so in order to make this tour happen this time we have decided to overcome the financial obstacle that came in our way in the beginning by doing this fundraising campaign. 

Any small help would make be useful in spreading the word of peace and justice that this tour is trying to achieve, I simply cannot afford to miss out on such opportunity.

 

(The invitation I have received from the House of Commons in London to exhibit early this year, but unfortunately I wasn't able to exhibit due to the financial obstacles) 

(Another invitation from Open Ealing Gallery of one month exhibiting)

 

More exhibitions, workshops , artist talks are to be finalized in the next few weeks.

Some venues are to be booked upon the success of the this campaign.

Its is very important to secure the financial aspect of this trip  in order to arrange more events and make more places feel comfortable that I have the resources to make this trip happen.

 

 

 

The recent bombing of art and culture institutions in Gaza:

Recently the two main centers for art and culture in Gaza were brutally obliterated. when this happened it wasn't just bricks and mortar that were destroyed but also many of the hopes and dreams of aspiring young artists in Gaza. Where art is a form of expression people in Palestine often have their voices silenced.

The art and craft village and the Meshal Arts center were also the first two places I had ever exhibited my art work, so when it was destroyed I was rather sentimental as were the whole artist community in Gaza, therefore this important tour in the UK comes to save and boost the Palestinian talents and give them the hope to carry on spreading the message of humanity and peace.

The $15,000 will be used to fund the following cost of my UK tour 2019

 

The Perks 

Since you decided to help me, I have decided to reward you with amazing art that you will get in return for the support. Please check out the perks on the right side of the screen. 

Ps: Please be patient with me, as you know I might be overwhelmed with so many drawings to create as well as the hard and time consuming work I need to put in promoting the campaign and lining up more events for the tour. Thanks in advance!

Some steps from the process of drawing 'Loud Summer 2016'

 

 

Risks and Challenges

Me and my dear friend Farzana Khan have been working hard on this tour, we have made a comprehensive plan of action and a schedule of events.

Farzana has 5 years experience in curating exhibitions and marketing, working with her is such a privilege, we are very excited to put our plans in action. To get in touch with Farzana, you can contact her at: the.olive.tree@outlook.com

The only obstacle which came in our way was the finances needed for the tour, and reaching our campaign goal will be the key to launch this tour and cover every aspect of it fully. We have also made the goal flexible so we can cover as many aspects of it as possible. 

We are 100% sure that we can achieve this and make you all proud of this achievement for humanity.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to the campaign, I totally understand. You can still help though!

I would appreciate every type of help you would offer either by sharing it on your social media accounts, telling a friend about it, or printing the leaflet and kindly distribute it where you work or study, I'm going to make the last option available in the next few days.

 

Feel free to visit my website and other social media accounts: 

Website: www.adamshartwork.wixsite.com/artist

Email: adamshartwork@gmail.com

FB: www.facebook.com/adamshdrawings

Instagram: www.instagram.com/adamshartwork
story_txt: Thanks to everyone who donated, we appreciate your kind support and encourage others to donate as the campaign has few days left till it wraps up.  INEXTINGUISHABLE SUNS TOUR SPRING 2019 At first glance you may be mistaken into thinking the two images below are a photograph, in fact they are hand drawn pencil artwork crafted by me.Immediately you are drawn in closer to the image to try and figure out if it’s a drawing or a photograph trying to capture the glisten of the graphite in the light, it is then that you are drawn in by the finite details... the wrinkles on the elderly lady's face or the stray white hairs individually defined on my grandfathers drawing, and its upon looking at the finite detail that you are transported to the time and place that tells the plight of the Palestinian cause.Allow me to introduce myself... I'm Adam Shehada a self taught hyper realistic pencil artist living under occupation in Gaza, Palestine.Hyper realistic pencil and charcoal drawings from my debut collection Inextinguishable Suns    My story As an artist from Gaza with a dream, I grew up not only witnessing but living the daily suffering caused by the occupationThe scenes and smell of dust filing the house choking us as the walls were being destroyed , the screams of mom trying to stop Israeli bulldozers before they kill us, that's only glimpse of what my memory could recall at the age of 11.The scene of death I saw that night and every night during the wars Gaza has been through still flash in my head with the fall of every new martyr or injured .My dream was to become an artist and animator who creates cartoons for children, I grew up and that dream was replaced with a much deeper one which is to advocate the rights of the oppressed children in the world through my talentI have spent many years teaching myself and refining my artistic skills, until I was able to earn the respect of some important local and international artists.And for this, I want to introduce you to my debut hyper realistic art collection titled ' Inextinguishable Suns', after years of hard work and dedicationToday I'm announcing the launch of my UK tour 2019, the purpose of it is to highlight 'in a very new artistic style' the suffering of children in Palestine in particular and their peers around the globe who are subjected to similar injustice in general. I explore the human values which must be given to these children who are the hope of the future in the worldI'm hoping to be able to achieve this dream of mine, and that could only happen if you guys decide to help me. Any amount/contribution would make a difference, no matter how small it is, it will be the pebble that build the mountain.I completely understand if you are not able to donate, you can share this post/campaign with your friends.  Who is Adam Shehada?I was born in 1991 in Gaza, Palestine .Since a very young age I have developed a passion for art and have spent much of my life pursuing this passion and refining my talents.I have participated in many local art activities, seminars, TV and radio interviews as well as holding hyper realism workshops of low registration fees to help other local artist further their artistic skills.I have always admired the artwork of the leading hyper realism artists internationally and as hyper realism is relatively new in Gaza the only way for me to develop my skills (as there were no hyper realism art classes held in Gaza at the time) was to look closely at the detail in the artworks of artists such as Kelvin Okafor, Paul Cadden, Gotfried Henlwen and Samantha Messias and through a process of trial and error I tried to recapture their methods. Over the years I have developed a friendship with these artists, who have kindly offered support and advice with regards to how to develop my talents.In May 2018 I participated in an exhibition in Ramallah at Zawyeh gallery. My artwork was displayed alongside the art of legendary Palestinian artists such as Suleiman Mansour but sadly due to the restrictions on travel I wasn't able to attend the exhibition.Despite my noticeable talent, my artworks never bypassed the borders of Palestine due to the complications and restrictions imposed by the occupation; therefore this opportunity to exhibit my collection in the UK seems to come just in the right time.  Me standing next to my artwork is such a perfect chance for my art t get the recognition it deserves and to personally tell the story behind each artwork.We believe that the world should see the best of Palestinian talents that live under occupation. Artist of The Month on 'This Week In Palestine' Magazine 2018'   The significance of 'Inextinguishable Suns' Tour The significance of this creative tour doesn’t only lie in highlighting the suffering of oppressed in Palestine but also everyone who lacks the basic human rights around the world such as in Syria, Yemen, Africa, Burma and many other places which suffered from oppression and persecution for a very long time.'Inextinguishable Suns' is the first hyper realistic collection crafted by a Palestinian artist that narrates the hardships of the innocent people in Palestine especially children who are the most affected by war.To produce these drawings it took me hundreds or even thousands of working hours, dedication, patience and perseverance. Showcasing the narrative of the children and people who yearn for justice and freedom in a creative way will have a great impact on those decision makers, the people in the UK and even people from around the world who are going to see and hear about this event on the news.3.      The impact is going to be reflected on the people living in Gaza and Palestine, it will not only attract support towards the cause but also it will have a special effect on artists living there by giving them hope that they can achieve their dreams despite all odds.4. Having a chance to display my artwork in parliament will afford the people of the UK an opportunity to experience my artwork in the mother of parliaments, and to give me a platform to present my work to parliamentarians from both houses and the many staff who work in the parliament, is an opportunity that simply cannot be missed.  Invitations which are gonna be activated upon my arrival to the UK:When I found out that I was not able to meet the financial requirements to come to the UK and hold these important exhibitions below, I felt really disheartened, and since then me and my dear friend Farzana have been expanding our efforts in arranging more venues for the tour, so in order to make this tour happen this time we have decided to overcome the financial obstacle that came in our way in the beginning by doing this fundraising campaign. Any small help would make be useful in spreading the word of peace and justice that this tour is trying to achieve, I simply cannot afford to miss out on such opportunity. (The invitation I have received from the House of Commons in London to exhibit early this year, but unfortunately I wasn't able to exhibit due to the financial obstacles) (Another invitation from Open Ealing Gallery of one month exhibiting) More exhibitions, workshops , artist talks are to be finalized in the next few weeks.Some venues are to be booked upon the success of the this campaign.Its is very important to secure the financial aspect of this trip  in order to arrange more events and make more places feel comfortable that I have the resources to make this trip happen.   The recent bombing of art and culture institutions in Gaza:Recently the two main centers for art and culture in Gaza were brutally obliterated. when this happened it wasn't just bricks and mortar that were destroyed but also many of the hopes and dreams of aspiring young artists in Gaza. story:
Background

The Letterpress Studio at The Printing Museum offers many opportunities to learn letterpress printing, from formal workshops and private tutorials, to informal group printing and open studio programs. Artists can also rent studio time to print their creative projects. Our programs include: 

  • Ink & Drink – social group printing
  • Printing for Public Good – community printing projects
  • Open studio
  • Letterpress I, II, III
  • Letterpress cards and posters 

We also print letterpress cards, posters, and gift items in the studio for sale in our store to support museum operations.

Equipment

TYPE
The Printing Museum collects and maintains an impressive inventory of metal and wood type (complete typefaces from 6pt Garamond to 30-line/360pt gothic condensed and orphan type up to 80-line/960pt), ornamental borders, ornaments, and cuts. We make them available for use by novice and experienced artists in their printing projects.

 

PRESSES
The Printing Museum owns many presses of all shapes and sizes, generously donated by our founders and other area businesses and printing enthusiasts. Due to their age, and being out of use for so long, many presses require partial or extensive restoration to bring them back into working condition. Currently the Letterpress Studio houses: 

  • 1 – Chandler & Price Pilot Old Series platen press
  • 2 – Kelsey & Co. tabletop platen presses
  • 1 – Chandler & Price New Series platen press*
  • 1 – Vandercook No. 4 cylinder press*
  • 1 – Ostrander & Seymour Washington style proof press 

* Requires restoration

Wishlist

The popularity of our studio programs has outgrown our space and equipment. To meet our instructional and production needs, we need to acquire and restore cylinder and platen presses. 

  • 2 – Chandler & Price Pilot Old Series platen presses
  • 2 – Vandercook No. 4 or Universal I 
  • 1 – Large format, powered cylinder press (ex. Vandercook No. 425)
  • 1 – Polymer plate maker 
  • 1 – Power paper cutter with safety guard 

That is why our campaign goal is $25,000 — to spread the love of letterpress printing. Please consider supporting our campaign by purchasing one of our perks, all printed on vintage presses and, produced in the Letterpress Studio at The Printing Museum.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Keyth Neso.  I am an artist, pianist, composer, music producer/engineer/mixer, hypnotherapist, Tarologist, and creative risk-taker.

After twenty years in the professional recording industry (working with clients such as Coldplay, Antony & The Johnsons, Simon & Garfunkel, etc...), I am getting back to my roots as a classical pianist, composer, and visual artist, while incorporating newfound passions into a cohesive multimedia buffet of all I have to offer artistically, as an homage to the courageous life of my beloved grandmother, Dorothy, who passed in 1999.

A Soul Flies Home is intended to be my post-metamorphosis re-emergence as an artist, as I compose separate pieces of original music grounded in acoustic piano, and then use the orchestral vignettes as inspiration to create original large scale paintings and silent films to accompany the music and live performance, all to be captured in high resolution video and audio.

This is a huge undertaking that will serve as the timely culmination of the many different chapters of my life, and offer to the world a gift in honor of my grandmother.  I was not able to understand nor relate to the numerous difficulties she faced while she was still living, and this is my expressive attempt to let her know how much I care, across and through the boundaries of space and time.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This is a big project, and there is much work to be done.  I am asking for $53,000 to cover the costs and expenses of space, lighting, musicians, rehearsals, hardware and software, printed materials, promotion, creative effort and high-resolution audio and video capture, as well as live webcast.

Your donation can buy you a seat to the intimate and unique multimedia performance with world-class musicians, access to a private link for a live webcast, a professionally edited video of the performance, access to the making-of mini-documentary, large scale autographed prints of the original artworks, private links to the original films, original portraits of whomever you choose, original compositions and films to accompany them created just for you as an expression of gratitude for your support, dinner and conversation with me, the artist, or a handmade deck of Ancient Marseille Tarot cards.

 

The Impact

I hope the world premiere of this challenging and heartfelt multimedia experience will ripple out into the field far and wide, inspiring others to take big chances and dedicate themselves to their passions.  I hope to continue to perform this work after its premiere, and would be thrilled to have the experience live in the hearts of those it touched for years to come.

And I also hope Dorothy (AKA "Granny") witnesses the event from behind the veil as we celebrate the impact she had on my life with beautiful music and imagery.

 

Risks & Challenges

I have experience putting together large scale experiences, and there are always snags.  They will happen, and will be opportunities to grow and learn lessons.  With your support, I am certain I can deliver an experience that will not be forgotten, and it will live on in my heart forever.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I believe as humans our greatest achievement is our creativity.  Please share this campaign with benefactors and lovers of classical music, abstract art, and those who enjoy supporting artists that tend the thrive on the edge.

story:
Help CSAW Raise $25,000 to Create Another Year of Microgrants and a new Tuition Grant for Circus Artists of Color!

----

CSAW - Connecting Circus Students Around the World has now awarded a $1,000 Microgrant to a circus artist of color every month for a year (plus one more)!  Over 100 BIPOC circus artists applied for a grant. So we’re asking you to help us provide another year of Microgrants!

This time we are raising $25,000 to run our Microgrant program again AND to create a brand new tuition grant program. Both grant programs will provide funding resources for circus artists of color. This includes 12 more $1,000 monthly Microgrants and one $5,000 tuition grant. *See information on who is eligible, what a grant can be used for, etc. in our FAQ section!

The CSAW Microgrants for US Circus Artists of Color Program provided funding to BIPOC artists for projects from: starting a new company, producing a show, creating costuming, purchasing equipment, continuing training and helping to pay tuition for higher education programs. 

Meet the 2020-2021 Microgrant Recipients: https://youtu.be/4BAJWYlNxv8

To see how the thirteen Microgrant Recipients of 2020-2021 used their funding, watch the video above or visit https://www.csawcircus.org/financial-aid to learn more: 

CSAW is committed to taking action against racism in the circus community. As the world re-opens, let's not "go back to normal". Instead, let's create a more inclusive circus so we can learn, change, and grow together.

----

Are you interested in becoming a monthly donor for CSAW? Join our Patreon to support us year round! 

https://www.patreon.com/csawcircus

-----

WHY RAISE $25,000 THIS TIME? 

  • 12 more $1,000 Microgrants 
    • For US Circus Artists of Color - one for every month from October 2021 to October 2022. This program was so successful in its inaugural year that we hope to keep it growing and budding for years to come. Learn more: https://www.csawcircus.org/financial-aid

 

  • A brand new $5,000 Tuition Grant​
    • ​This new grant program will help us  serve our mission of greater accessibility to circus education!* Three of our 20-21 Microgrant recipients used their $1,000 to help fund their tuition at the National School in Montreal as well as at Circadium in Philadelphia.

*Circus education will be used as a broad term for the purpose of this grant, meaning  awardees can use the grant for applying to circus schools, higher education programs, prep programs, training, classes and anything that can be defined as further education in circus. For more information, visit our FAQ page.

 

  • $3,000 for the Selection Committees​
    • ​​All grant selection committees have and will continue to be composed of established circus artists of color within the community whose names shall remain anonymous. We are so grateful for our 20-21 selection committee for all of the help they have provided to CSAW! A portion of the funds will go toward ensuring that these committee members are compensated for their time.

 

* Remaining funds will go toward administrative, advertising, and Indiegogo fees, as well as to the longevity of future CSAW programming. 

* As of August 2020, CSAW is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit. If you would like for your donation to be tax deductible,​ you may request a tax receipt by emailing info@csawcircus.org

----

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

  • Donate!
    •  Monetary donations are the lifeblood of our fundraiser, so every bit helps! Your money goes directly toward making grants for circus artists of color.

 

  • Matched Donation​
    • ​ Last year, matched donations were responsible for over half of the $20,000 raised. Email info@csawcircus.org with the amount that you would like to match and we'll work together to challenge people to meet your amount! 

 

  • Pledge a % of Your Event
    • Do you have an upcoming live event? Or a virtual one? YAY! You can pledge to donate a certain dollar amount of ticket sales, etc. to CSAW. We’ll promote your event and you can encourage your audience members to donate!

 

  • Promotion!
    • ​Share our fundraiser with your platform! Repost our content, reach out to figure out a cross-promotion plan with us, or tell your friends to donate. Anything you can do to help spread the word is greatly appreciated.

 

  • Ongoing Learning & Changing
    • How are your anti-racism policies and training going? What needs updates, how can you keep working to learn and change? CSAW needs to do this ongoing work too. Let’s help hold each other accountable.

----

----

More Info: 

CSAW recognizes that funding and access to money is not the only barrier for circus artists of color and that there is so much more work to be done to fight systemic racism in the circus community and the United States at large. CSAW is working with existing non-profits to create an infrastructure that would allow for long-term donors and more significant funding opportunities to be created. We are also continuing conversations and learning to find where the need for funding truly lies in the circus. Receiving applications for these grants will help us continue to identify which area of circus is most in need of support. For any feedback, inquiries, or other information contact info@csawcircus.org or visit https://www.csawcircus.org/.

CSAW - Connecting Circus Students Around the World was founded by Sierra Rhoades Nicholls in 2018 to increase accessibility of information and funding for students of international circus schools. Through an increase of knowledge, resources, community, and financial aid CSAW strives to assist future circus artists in finding the pathways best for them.

Sierra Rhoades Nicholls, founder of CSAW, is white. She recognizes the potential for this fundraiser to look and feel like white saviorism. This is not her intention and she is trying to ensure that in the campaign and fundraising, she neither centers herself, nor whiteness. CSAW is endeavoring to amplify the voices of as many US circus artists of color as possible without tokenizing them. All featured circus artists have given their permission for the use of their work.

CSAW would also like to recognize that in spite of their best efforts, the above or similar harmful practices might happen anyway. In the fight for social justice, mistakes will inevitably be made. If you would  like to call us out, or if you have any concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to contact CSAW in the following ways: 

Email : info@csawcircus.org 

Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/csawcircus/

Instagram : https://www.instagram.com/csaw_circus/

Website : https://www.csawcircus.org/

Twitter : https://twitter.com/CsawThe

YouTube Channel : https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIDfUsWIjzZb9ExJ-E3a5EQ

TikTok: https://vm.tiktok.com/ZMdWeYFfh/
story_txt:
Help CSAW Raise $25,000 to Create Another Year of Microgrants and a new Tuition Grant for Circus Artists of Color!----CSAW - Connecting Circus Students Around the World has now awarded a $1,000 Microgrant to a circus artist of color every month for a year (plus one more)!  Over 100 BIPOC circus artists applied for a grant. So we’re asking you to help us provide another year of Microgrants!This time we are raising $25,000 to run our Microgrant program again AND to create a brand new tuition grant program. Both grant programs will provide funding resources for circus artists of color. This includes 12 more $1,000 monthly Microgrants and one $5,000 tuition grant. *See information on who is eligible, what a grant can be used for, etc. in our FAQ section!The CSAW Microgrants for US Circus Artists of Color Program provided funding to BIPOC artists for projects from: starting a new company, producing a show, creating costuming, purchasing equipment, continuing training and helping to pay tuition for higher education programs. Meet the 2020-2021 Microgrant Recipients: https://youtu.be/4BAJWYlNxv8To see how the thirteen Microgrant Recipients of 2020-2021 used their funding, watch the video above or visit https://www.csawcircus.org/financial-aid to learn more: CSAW is committed to taking action against racism in the circus community. As the world re-opens, let's not "go back to normal". Instead, let's create a more inclusive circus so we can learn, change, and grow together.----Are you interested in becoming a monthly donor for CSAW? Join our Patreon to support us year round! https://www.patreon.com/csawcircus-----WHY RAISE $25,000 THIS TIME? 
12 more $1,000 Microgrants For US Circus Artists of Color - one for every month from October 2021 to October 2022. This program was so successful in its inaugural year that we hope to keep it growing and budding for years to come. Learn more: https://www.csawcircus.org/financial-aid

 
A brand new $5,000 Tuition Grant​​This new grant program will help us  serve our mission of greater accessibility to circus education!* Three of our 20-21 Microgrant recipients used their $1,000 to help fund their tuition at the National School in Montreal as well as at Circadium in Philadelphia.
*Circus education will be used as a broad term for the purpose of this grant, meaning  awardees can use the grant for applying to circus schools, higher education programs, prep programs, training, classes and anything that can be defined as further education in circus. For more information, visit our FAQ page. 
$3,000 for the Selection Committees​​​All grant selection committees have and will continue to be composed of established circus artists of color within the community whose names shall remain anonymous. We are so grateful for our 20-21 selection committee for all of the help they have provided to CSAW! A portion of the funds will go toward ensuring that these committee members are compensated for their time.
 * Remaining funds will go toward administrative, advertising, and Indiegogo fees, as well as to the longevity of future CSAW programming. * As of August 2020, CSAW is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit. If you would like for your donation to be tax deductible,​ you may request a tax receipt by emailing info@csawcircus.org----HOW CAN YOU HELP?
Donate! Monetary donations are the lifeblood of our fundraiser, so every bit helps! Your money goes directly toward making grants for circus artists of color.
 
Matched Donation​​ Last year, matched donations were responsible for over half of the $20,000 raised. Email info@csawcircus.org with the amount that you would like to match and we'll work together to challenge people to meet your amount! 
 
Pledge a % of Your EventDo you have an upcoming live event? Or a virtual one? YAY! You can pledge to donate a certain dollar amount of ticket sales, etc. to CSAW. We’ll promote your event and you can encourage your audience members to donate!
 
Promotion!​Share our fundraiser with your platform! Repost our content, reach out to figure out a cross-promotion plan with us, or tell your friends to donate. Anything you can do to help spread the word is greatly appreciated.
 
Ongoing Learning & ChangingHow are your anti-racism policies and training going? What needs updates, how can you keep working to learn and change? CSAW needs to do this ongoing work too. Let’s help hold each other accountable.
--------More Info: CSAW recognizes that funding and access to money is not the only barrier for circus artists of color and that there is so much more work to be done to fight systemic racism in the circus community and the United States at large. CSAW is working with existing non-profits to create an infrastructure that would allow for long-term donors and more significant funding opportunities to be created. We are also continuing conversations and learning to find where the need for funding truly lies in the circus. Receiving applications for these grants will help us continue to identify which area of circus is most in need of support. For any feedback, inquiries, or other information contact info@csawcircus.org or visit https://www.csawcircus.org/.CSAW - Connecting Circus Students Around the World was founded by Sierra Rhoades Nicholls in 2018 to increase accessibility of information and funding for students of international circus schools. Through an increase of knowledge, resources, community, and financial aid CSAW strives to assist future circus artists in finding the pathways best for them.Sierra Rhoades Nicholls, founder of CSAW, is white. She recognizes the potential for this fundraiser to look and feel like white saviorism. This is not her intention and she is trying to ensure that in the campaign and fundraising, she neither centers herself, nor whiteness. CSAW is endeavoring to amplify the voices of as many US circus artists of color as possible without tokenizing them. All featured circus artists have given their permission for the use of their work.CSAW would also like to recognize that in spite of their best efforts, the above or similar harmful practices might happen anyway. In the fight for social justice, mistakes will inevitably be made. If you would  like to call us out, or if you have any concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to contact CSAW in the following ways: Email : info@csawcircus.org Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/csawcircus/Instagram : https://www.instagram.com/csaw_circus/Website : https://www.csawcircus.org/Twitter : https://twitter.com/CsawTheYouTube Channel : https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIDfUsWIjzZb9ExJ-E3a5EQTikTok: https://vm.tiktok.com/ZMdWeYFfh/

story:
FOLKLORE started as a 100 day drawing project on Instagram during the third UK lockdown in December 2020. I wanted to give myself  something fun and magical to focus on in the depths of winter, inspired  by the folk tales, folk music and wildlife of the UK and Ireland. 

 

I challenged myself to make 100 drawings. As the days went by, I had to dig deeper and deeper into English, Scots, Welsh, Irish, Manx and Cornish lore, and I began sharing the stories I found as narrated videos on TikTok. The response was so enthusiastic I kept going with the project after lockdown ended. Nearly 47,000 people have followed along with these tales over Instagram and Tiktok, over half a million likes over both platforms, with hundreds of people sharing their own memories and local retellings of these much loved tales.

Now all 100 drawings are complete, it's time to share them in their physical form, for those of you who (like me) just dig the feel of pages under your fingers. After hundreds of hours of work, and the success of these stories online, I am so excited to share my first book, Folklore - Tales Of These Isles with you all.

The book is not a comprehensive guide to UK/Celtic Nations folklore - I am not an expert, and there are too many amazing stories for me to cover in just one volume! Instead, it's a selection of retellings of the stories and characters I've been most enchanted by as I started to dig deeper into this lore, along with a few introduced to me by commenters.  The book will include a bibliography and a list of folklore resources for backers who would like a starting point to look further into these stories. It also features a special new tale by guest writer Sasha Greenlan.

In the proper folklore tradition, a few of the stories do contain violence and horror. Whilst Folklore is intended to be shared across generations, reader discretion is advised, and you might want to read through yourself or browse back through the TikTok page before gifting to readers under the age of 12.

December 2020 - August 2021 - Lovingly illustrate 100 images inspired by folk tales and folk music, and write some fun retellings of their stories to go along with them. (This is the hard bit, and it's already done!)

August-September 2021 - The Kickstarter campaign for Folklore - Tales of These Isles was a success! 762 backers pledged £33,446 to help bring this book to life.

September-October 2021 - We are here! The book is currently in production.

November 2021 - Dispatching all physical rewards from Kickstarter campaign via Royal Mail International. 

December 2021 - January 2022 - Dispatching all physical rewards from IndieGoGo campaign, book available for general sale. Beginning rollout of Audio Companion content via PopUpView.

 

Hi, I'm Hannah - if you're here, you might know me through my illustration and tattoo work (@mosleytattoos on Instagram and @mosleydraws on TikTok). I live in Manchester with my partner Nate (whose voice you may have heard on some of my stories), our two kids and a pair of formerly-stray cats. We like making stories for your eyes and ears. Thank you so much for reading this far and your interest in Folklore - all your support has made a very difficult year so much more enjoyable.

story:
Famous Artist Portfolio Program

Since 1985, Turtle Bay Exploration Park and its predecessor museum, Redding Museum of Art & History have brought museum-quality art lessons to Shasta County children (grades K-6), through the Famous Artist Portfolio Program. 

Trained volunteers visit local classrooms throughout the year, choosing from over 70 ready-made lesson plans and art activities featuring famous artists. This program teaches art in fun & hands-on way, offers extra-help to busy teachers,and culminates each year in a museum-quality exhibition at Turtle Bay where students and their families can view their own art in a professional setting. 

At a time when school art budgets are low AND we know the positive effects of STEAM (science, technology, engineering, art, and mathematics) education, it is more important than ever to encourage a love of the arts in our youngest students.

Our Kids Need You!

To keep this awesome program going, we are seeking a total of $5,000 of support. 

This covers: 

  • Program management (staff support) - $2,500
  • Volunteer training - $500
  • Materials & supplies - $1,500
  • Exhibition of works - $200
  • Marketing - $300 (for volunteer recruitment & exhibition promotion)

If we fall short of our goal, we will still apply all donated funds to this project and continue to do our best to keep it going in a limited number of classrooms.

If we EXCEED our goal (!!!), additional proceeds will support other free art programming at Turtle Bay, such as the Museum Art Gallery Experience (MAGE) on-site tour and art project for Shasta County 3rd graders.  

If we  exceed our goal and raise more than $10,000, funds will go toward booking future interdisciplinary art exhibitions at the Turtle Bay Museum to be enjoyed by the community.  Past examples include: Picasso: 25 Years of Edition Ceramics, Women Only: Artists in Their Studios, West Coast Biennial: Juried Art Exhibition, and Ansel Adams Masterworks,

Big Impact

This program has been getting kids excited about visual arts for 30 years!   During the 2014-2015 school year, 35 volunteers reached 1,700+ kids at 19 area schools! But there's room to grow.   With full financial support, we believe we can increase the number of classrooms participating, through building a larger volunteer pool.  And through comparative metrics, we know students who get to experience this program have an increased appreciation of art and feel more confident and positive about creating their own artworks! 
Curious about Turtle Bay's big budget picture?  Visit Turtle Bay's Quick Reference Guide on our website.  

Need more data on how much art can impact children?  Check out these links:

American's for the Arts Research on Arts & Education

The Importance of Art in Child Development (PBS)

NEA Research Report Shows Benefits of Arts Education for At-Risk Youth

Short on cash?

There are many ways to help!
  • Spread the word using IndieGoGo share tools
  • Volunteer for the Famous Artists Outreach Program!  Learn more on Turtle Bay's Education Website

story:
Hello! My name is Gina Lomeli. Also known as Electric Fairy.

My creation!

I am raising funds for an art installation called Electric Ocean, for an event called Youtopia. Electric Ocean will be a series of umbrella jellyfish with Christmas lights hanging from two lifted gazebo tents. Underneath the jellyfish will be two inflatable pools with pillows and blankets for the participants of the event to enjoy laying in while enjoying my electric ocean.

How my dream was born.

Electric Ocean came to be a spark of an idea amidst the lights and art of festivals. After witnessing several handmade jellyfish throughout the years I started to envision an underwater world with lots of lights to hang a school of jellyfish. So that one could be transported to an oceanic dream.

Myself, my loved ones and my contributors.

I am a San Francisco State alumni with a B.A. in theater. Used to the performance aspect of art I have always been timid about creating physical art. I have always harbored the creativity within me, however it took some tugging and pulling to give me the courage to take a leap and try my hand at it. My sister, an artist, my boyfriend, an entrepreneur, my loving family and my festival families all finally gave me the push I needed. With all of their support I gained the courage to start Electric Ocean and to make my dream come to life.

The budget breakdown.

These are the materials needed to complete Electric Ocean to its fullest capacity.

2 gazebo tents   279.98

10 umbrellas  98.90

10 led Christmas lights  94.90

Box of nails  1.99

10 yard polyester fabric  69.99

Acrylic paint  34.99

Hand crafting materials  35.00

Inflatable pools  59.98

Fabric for blankets/pillows  34.93

6 sawhorses  90.00

120 batteries (umbrella lights)  45.00

Gas from San Diego to La Jolla

Indian Campgrounds Roundtrip 166.50

Total: 1012.16

Amount Donated by San Diego Collaborative Arts Project and my own contribution

total: 390.00

Amount requested: 622.16

Other Nifty Things

My website; www.electricfairyware.com

Facebook; Gina Lomeli (electric fairy)

Twitter; Dayumn_Gina

Instagram; mashpotatobrain

A final word.

I believe that I can create a dream world. There will be difficulties getting my art to the site and finding the time while working and going to school to make it. But I know I have the determination to make it happen. I had only attended Youtopia last year and was so inspired to try and make art this year. I hope with my Electric Ocean, that I can inspire someone like me to make their dreams come true. So I’m putting all my heart into it and giving it everything I have.

Thank you for all for the love and support!

-Electric Fairy

story:
WOZA! Support South African Youth to Tell Their Stories

WOZA! is an open art experience where we use youth-centered, participatory methods to engage youth in the art and practice of storytelling through visual media. 

WOZA! will being going to South Africa to work directly with a team of youth in rural KwaZulu-Natal to develop, produce and share their stories - locally and worldwide. 

  • 1. TELL YOUR STORY 
  • 2. MAKE YOUR STORY
  • 3. SHARE YOUR STORY

Our goal is empower youth with the knowledge, skills and experience to produce their stories into works of art and share them with their communities and the world to create awareness and encourage resources into the community to create a youth-centred visual arts program.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising $10,000.  This will cover project costs including: stipends for project partners and staff who will facilitate linkages within the community, interviewers, translators, transportation and fuel, food for participants, sound recording, and costs for a community event where youth will share their work.
  • After all the projects are created and shared within the community we will return first to Canada and hold an Art Gallery Event to exhibit the work, with hopes to raise awareness and funds to continue this work. 

The Impact

Our youth-centered, participatory approach to creating visual media is designed to promote confidence, awareness and capacity to advocate for positive change. 

The first participants in WOZA! are youth born just after 1994 -- the first generation of children born after the end of apartheid. Although 'born free', the majority of South African youth are growing up in extremely challenging circumstances due to the intertwined effects of unemployment and poverty, including high levels of food insecurity, HIV and TB, unplanned pregnancies, and violence. Further, many youth are growing up without their parents as a result of HIV/AIDS -- over half of all orphans under 18 years old are adolescents 12 to 17 years old. 

WOZA! will give youth the opportunity to voice their experiences, needs, and dreams through visual media. Further, they will gain new skills and experience in the various aspects of media production, guided by a team from Canada, the US, South Africa and Zimbabwe including members with expertise in film, photography, storytelling, adolescent health, participatory design methods and community development. WOZA! will ensure that the stories and images produced with and by the youth are shared locally -- in their own community -- as well as internationally. 

The Budget

Past Projects

We wanted to share a few past projects members of our team have worked on in the past... Enjoy 
DEAR 16 YEAR OLD ME  

This film was made possible thanks to the generosity of real Canadians and Americans whose lives have been touched by melanoma. These are not actors. We cannot thank this group enough for sharing their stories with us. 
Craig Henry: camera operator and assistent editor.   Working alongside a great team at Evidently.


THE POWER OF KNOWING 

Worldwide, there are about 3.3 million children under 15 years of age living with HIV. Despite the many benefits of knowing their status, the vast majority of these children, even amongst those on treatment, have not been told that they are HIV positive. The Power of Knowing reveals the stories of young South Africans who have found out their status and recounts their experience – and those of their primary caregivers. 

This film was produced by Lisa M. Butler, directed by Robert Inglis and Hilary Kromberg of Jive Media Africa, and done in collaboration with the Sinomlando Centre for Oral History and Memory Work

Other Ways You Can Help

Contributing funds funds isn't the only way you can help there are many way to get involved. 

  • Get the word out there.  Share this with your peers with the Indiegogo share tools!
  • If you have a medium you would like to help Youths take part in,  maybe we can collaborate.  Painting, Sculpture, Dance anything don't hesitate to contact us and see other ways YOU can get involved.


And that's all there is to it.
