program.



Jhon Galaviz (fotografía cortesía: Lotty Guerra)

Nace en la ciudad de San Cristóbal, ingresa al aprendizaje musical a través del canto coral; fue miembro de las agrupaciones corales Coro ULA, Coro del Ateneo del Táchira, Coral del Colegio de Médicos, Escoralli Voces Oscuras, San Cristóbal Ensamble y participa en numerosos encuentros y festivales corales y sinfónico-corales a nivel nacional e internacional. Recibe sus conocimientos básicos de lenguaje musical y guitarra popular del Maestro Gregory Pino y de otros de sus compañeros ya aventajados en la teoría y ejecución musical. Formaliza sus estudios de guitarra clásica y es alumno del Maestro Pedro Angel, docente de La Academia Superior de Artes de Bogotá; Maestro Ignacio Ornés en el Conservatorio de Música Simón Bolívar de Caracas; Actualmente cursa sus estudios de guitarra en la Escuela de Música (Facultad de Arte Universidad de los Andes) en la ciudad de Mérida con el Maestro Carlos Oballos. Ha participado en clases magistrales con los Maestros Luis Zea (II Festival Internacional de Guitarra GUITCA, Caracas), John Jiménez (Perspectivas, Valera Edo. Trujillo) y Maestro Rafael Suárez (Escuela de Música Miguel Angel Espinel). Estudiante del décimo semestre de la Licenciatura en Música UNET,  se desempeña como Instructor de la cátedra de guitarra en FUNDAMUSICAL Bolívar y director de la Orquesta del Programa Alma Llanera del Módulo Pirineos y del Municipio San Cristóbal.
Amarú Vanegas (Mérida, 1977)



Industrial engineer, poet, theatre and cinema
actress, director and producer. Currently working on her thesis for a Master’s
Degree in Latin American and Caribbean Literature, with Los Andes University.
She has published the dramatic monologue Mortis (2001) and a book of poems The
fish song (2007). Founder and director of the group Purpura Poesia Escena, who
have been holding poetic gatherings since 2012 in San Cristóba-Venezuela,
Cúcuta-Colombia and Buenos Aires-Argentina. A cultural promoter, she delivers
reading and literary creation workshops, as well as many other cultural events
and activities. Founder of Catharsis Theatre and Book Trueque (exchanges) in
San Cristobal. She has participated in more than 40 theatre pieces and received
local and binational awards as best actress, director and playwriter. Finalist
in the V International Story Contest in Spain Storybox (2016).


Amarú Vanegas (fotografía cortesía: Igor Castillo)

Es Ingeniera industrial, poeta, actriz,  directora y productora de teatro y cine. Tesista en la maestría de Literatura Latinoamericana y del Caribe ULA. Ha publicado el monólogo teatral Mortis (2001) y el poemario El Canto de pez (2007). Fundadora y directora de la agrupación Púrpura Poesía Escena que ha realizado Tertulias Poéticas y Artísticas desde julio del 2012 en San Cristóbal- Venezuela, Cúcuta- Colombia y Buenos Aires -Argentina. Facilitadora de talleres de promoción de lectura y creación literaria. Es además organizadora y promotora de eventos culturales y fundadora de los grupos Catharsis Teatro y Trueque de libros SC. Tiene en su haber más de 40 montajes teatrales y ha recibido premios regionales y fronterizos como mejor actriz de reparto, directora y dramaturga. 3cer finalista en el V Concurso Internacional de Relatos de Sttorybox España (2016).






Elimar Montes
She
begins dancing at 7 years old, in the National Dance School. Graduates from
this program in 2014 with a degree as ballerina interpreter in Contemporary
Dance. Since 2014, she works with the Puropie Danza Contemporanea company. She
also mantains a place as Teacher in the National Dance School. 


Elimar Montes (fotografía cortesía: Igor Castillo)
Inicia sus estudios en danza desde los 7 años en la Escuela Nacional de Danza (Endanza) graduada en el año 2014, recibe el titulo como bailarina intérprete en Danza contemporánea. Desde el año 2014 es Bailarina en la Compañía Puropie Danza contemporánea, también se desempeña como Docente en la Escuela Nacional de Danza.






Vladimir Hoyos (San Cristóbal, 1996)


 
High
performance gymnast. He starts training at 11 years old, in the Alba Jáuregui
Gym. His incursion in the world of classical and contemporary dancing begins at
age 18, with Entredanza academy. Currently working with Puropie Danza
Contemporanea Company. He also is studying Social Communication in Los Andes
University, Tachira. 



Vladimir Hoyos (fotografía cortesía: Daniel Cáceres)
Gimnasta de alta competencia. Comienza sus entrenamientos deportivos a la edad de 11 años formándose en el pabellón de Gimnasia Alba Jáuregui. Incursiona en el mundo de la danza clásica y contemporánea a los 18 años en el centro de formación integral Entredanza, se desempeña como Bailarín en la Compañía Puropie Danza Contemporánea dirigido por Liz Pérez. Actualmente cursa el primer año de comunicación social en la Universidad de los Andes, Núcleo Táchira.


Roselbi García (San Cristóbal, 1998)
Was born in San Cristobal-Tachira. She Start her dancing studies at the age of 6 in the Youth Ballet of Tachira, when she was 10, she begins in the National School of Dance "ENDANZA" in the same State. After 7 years, she graduated as a Contemporary Dancer In Endanza. From 2011 and till 2015 she dances in the Contemporary Dance Academy "Artnmoviento". She is also a teacher in different Academy's like: "M&M" dance studies, "ELITTE" Academy and "Amor Gitano" Flamenco Academy.




Roselbi García (fotografía cortesía: Paúl Chávez)
Roselbi Paola García Colmenares, nacida en San Cristóbal estado Táchira Inicia sus estudios en danza desde los 6 años de edad en el ballet juvenil del Táchira  y a los 10 años ingresa en la Escuela Nacional de Danza (Endanza) Táchira, graduada en el año 2015 recibe el titulo como bailarina intérprete en Danza contemporánea. Desde el 2011 hasta el 2015 bailarina de la compañia Artenmovimiento Danza Contemporánea, también se desempeña como Docente en diferentes academias; Estudio de Danza M&M, Academia Integral ELITTE y en Academia de flamenco Amor Gitano.





Anger Moncada



Since
age 17, he starts training in Santa Bárbara de Rubio nationalist dance company.
Moving through several groups, such as Venezuelan Remembrances and Tachira
Dances. In 2010 he enters the National Dance School, where he studies to
graduate as a professional dancer. Currently he works with Puropie Danza
Contemporanea Company.
Anger Moncada (fotografía cortesía: Lotty Guerra)
A los 17 años ingresa a la
Fundación Cultural Santa Bárbara de Rubio agrupación de danza nacionalista.
Recorre agrupaciones como Remembranzas Venezolanas y Danzas Táchira. En el 2010
se inscribe en la Escuela Nacional de Danza (ENDANZA) donde estudia para
graduarse como intérprete de Danza. Actualmente se desempeña como Bailarín en
la Compañía Puropie Danza Contemporánea.
Our goal / Nuestra meta:

We wish to share our
creative experience in many places, explore and meet with others in one huge heartbeat, floating aboard
this project that helps us in the process of soul-making.
Queremos
compartir nuestra experiencia creativa en muchos espacios,
explorar y coincidir en la plenitud de un gran latido, flotando a bordo de este
proyecto que nos ayuda a hacer alma.


Respiraciones (fotografía cortesía: Lotty Guerra)

Why support us? / ¿Por qué
apoyar este proyecto?

Art, humanities and creativity promotion may not be heroic, but we believe that these
small and constant activities result in valuable outcomes that contribute
significantly towards social change, daily building the country and the world
that we want and we know is possible. While others promise salvation
of the country through political or economic measures, we continue working,
nonstop, because we believe in what we do and it is the top priority
for us. 
El arte, las humanidades y
la promoción cultural puede que no sean heroicas,
pero creemos que estas actividades constantes tienen un resultado valioso,
y que contribuimos significativamente con el cambio
social, construyendo cotidianamente la región y el país que queremos. Mientras
otros prometen salvar al país a través de medidas políticas o económicas,
nosotros seguimos trabajando sin parar, porque creemos en lo que
hacemos y para nosotros es prioridad. 


Milonga (fotografía cortesía: Lotty Guerra)


Where does the money go? / ¿A dónde va el dinero?


We need
your support to travel with our show to the 7th International Scenic Arts CONTINOUS MOVEMENT in Bogotá, 2016.
Necesitamos tu apoyo para
viajar con nuestro espectáculo a la VII
Muestra Internacional de Artes Escénicas "MOVIMIENTO CONTINUO" Bogotá
2016.


El Decamerón negro (fotografía cortesía: Lotty Guerra)

Other ways to collaborate / Otras formas de colaborar

If for whatever reason you can not help
us with your contribution, perhaps you can help us by sharing this project
Si por el motivo que fuera no
puedes ayudarnos con tu aportación, quizás puedes ayudarnos compartiendo
este proyecto.

story: Event was moved to NYC.
story_txt: Event was moved to NYC.

story:
Many thanks to everyone who contributed to our Phase 1 Campaign  Your contributions helped us build our LED color changing Channel Sign, furnish our Black Light Lounge, and start our Ocean Beach Mural.

We are launching this Phase 2 Campaign to help us complete the rest of the projects we have designed for our Ocean Beach tasting room, including an interactive Light Brite display, interactive lighting controls at your table, custom designed patio panels by local artists, and a giant rain motion oil lamp, just to name a few.  

The campaign is flexible, which means that even if we don't meet our campaign goal, we are still able to put your contributions towards making our OB tasting room a one of a kind experience!

Who is Kilowatt?

If you've been to Kilowatt's brewery and tasting room in Kearny Mesa, you already know our creativity extends well beyond our tap list. 

At Kilowatt Brewing, we handcraft our beer in small three-barrel batches. Our passion for experimenting with unconventional ingredients and flavor profiles gives our customers the chance to sip on brews such as our Chocolate Macadamia Nut Stout, Passion Fruit Green Tea Ale, and our Hoptastic Voyage single hop IPA series, just to name a few. No matter how many times you go to our nanobrewery, each visit will feel different thanks to an ever-changing selection of 18–20 brews on tap, rotating galleries of local artwork, custom LED lights that regularly change the color and mood of the taproom, and food-pairing events with local chefs and food trucks.

Our Vision for Kilowatt Ocean Beach

We are super excited to be opening our second tasting room in Ocean Beach.  Ocean Beach was selected not only because two of our owners are OBecians, but also because the creativity and atmosphere of our brewery is a natural fit with the infamous Ocean Beach vibe.  

Our vision for this second location is to uniquely incorporate the creative energy of the Ocean Beach community into a one of a kind tasting room.  Collaborations with local artists already in design include a black light art installation, life size interactive Light Brite display, ocean beach art murals, and custom programmed LED lighting that will allow staff and customers to change the lighting color and mood in real-time.  We want Kilowatt Ocean Beach to be a creative space for the community to collaborate and gather (kid and dog friendly) and an iconic destination that will help contribute to the already thriving Ocean Beach economy.

How Can You Help?

We are a completely self-funded nano brewery and of course, all of this uniqueness comes with a price. But this is where you can help.  

We've put together a collection of awesome perks for your support, including:

  • Sweet Swag Options
  • Get your Name on the Kilowatt OB Mural
  • Private Patio Parties
  • 20 oz. Pours for the Price of 16 oz. FOREVER
  • 20% Off Growler Fills FOREVER, Brew Your Own Recipe
  • Tickets to the OB Soft Opening
  • Name Your Own Production Beer
  • Brew It With Us Sessions
  • Create It With Us Sessions

We have set up a flexible campaign, so every contribution will help us make Kilowatt Ocean Beach that much more special.

Risks & Challenges

We don't anticipate any challenges except for the typical hurdles involved in opening a second location.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can't contribute, or want to do even more to help and we can certainly use as much help as you can give! Here are other things you can do to give us a hand:

  • Tell other beer and art lovers about this campaign.
  • Share this campaign opportunity on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, and every other social median you have your disposal. Indiegogo has all the sharing tools one could dream of to make this easy.
  • If you have any blogging friends, or know any journalists or news personalities, please let them know about this, and ask them to reach out to beer@kilowatt.beer for more information or if they'd like to talk to one of us. 

We can't wait to open in Ocean Beach.

Thank you!

Team Kilowatt

story:
Everyone at least once in their lifetime has tried to draw. How many people get frustrated and stop drawing as the result of improper reproduction of the drawing subject? 

Precisely this problem with getting correct proportions and the development of this skill is a crucial step in getting into the world of art.

We've designed for you Tanto to help you to develop a sense of proportion and  master drawing skills.

Each Tanto has a centimetre or inch ruler, which helps you get proportions precisely and accurately.That is why, with Tanto, you can measure any object you would like to draw and get proportions correctly.




What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $8,000 to pay for the cost of everything that's needed to produce Tanto in proper volume with an inexpensive price. 

The donations you give us will be used to fund production of Tanto along with packaging materials.

Every penny will be used to pay for making Tanto into a reality.

In return, you will get the coolest device which will help you to learn drawing and develop a sense of  proportion.

With your generous help, we can bring Tanto to the market at an affordable price.

The Impact

We are a small and brand new company and without you, we cannot make it. Every donation matters to us, and this campaign determines whether or not we will able to bring Tanto to market. Without your contributions, we cannot afford to pay for manufacturing on our own, so please donate! 

With your help, we will help everyone who has a passion for art to learn to draw and to develop their skills faster and more easily.

story:
Marco who never went to art school was inspired by his 2nd Grade Art class. To this day it is the CHILDREN who are Marco's Teacher 

Hello, my name is Marco I'm a POP Artist based in NYC I travel the world doing
painting events with Children many of whom suffer from debilitating diseases I've been to Japan, the Philippines, Germany, and most recently the Middle East where I created huge murals for a special needs center and held painting clinics for children
many of whose families are very poor. 


Please help me to continue to use my talent to put smiles on the faces of these children After a year on the road I've recently returned to New York City Where, with your help, I will be able to establish a Children's art center where children from all over the world can come to paint and express themselves

I know first hand how important it is for Children to have a place where they can be free to unleash their creativity When I was only seven years old the classes in school were already beginning to become structured

For instance playtime became Gym class where on any given day the program was already established

This means that even if on Tuesday I wanted to play volleyball, Nina wanted to play
dodge ball, Ricky wanted to play football, David wanted to play baseball, Mary wanted to play basketball, ALL of his had to play hockey if that was the designated sport on the schedule

The same was true for the rest of the classes as early as 2nd Grade...With the one conspicuous exception being Art Class

In art class my teacher gave all of us a piece of paper, a pencil and told us to do
whatever we wanted. While some children, already accustomed to the rigid
structure of the rest of the school day became confused, intimidated, and even afraid, others, myself included welcomed the freedom of expression and relished every second...

To this day everything I create starts with the same blank piece of paper, wall, canvas and I feel the same sense of freedom of escaping into a world of my own creation that lives forever in the child that is alive and well in me.

Children are my teachers, they have in them all the unpolluted cosmic power of the universe and need little coaxing to create...just the piece of paper or canvas pencils, and paint that we supply them with


Please help me continue to help them express themselves so that as they grow into adults, like me they will carry with them the freedom that allows them to view the world in it's entirety with an open heart and mind.

Qualities that are indispensable in the increasingly complex, confusing technology-ruled world we live in.

Please join me in helping me create and establish a wonderful place where children
from all over the world can come to express themselves and leave a feeling of empowerment and freedom that they'll carry with them and draw on...

to draw on, and on...creating a better world for themselves and future generations.

If we, who have the power, do what we can to help provide those who will shape the world of the future with priceless tools they'll always use and never loose, we've can say we've done some good.

For your help I will send every one of you who a signed artwork that I created, the more you give the more amazing of a piece of artwork will you receive, from a print all the way to an original acrylic on canvas painting.

Thank you so much for being part of the Marcoart Children's Painting Place project.

Making Children create a better world, one sketch at a time.

story:
Our Mission

The Pendulum Project is a year-long collaborative curatorial initiative to increase the exposure and recognition of students and emerging artists in Toronto and build community through art and conversation.

Curatorial Statement
Our curatorial aim is to collaboratively manifest the talent of students and aspiring art professionals through a multidisciplinary investigation of themes pertaining to migration, marginalization and identity. Our exhibition series is centred around empowerment and will focus on unravelling the ambiguity of contemporary social issues such as political apathy and racial, religious and gender-based discrimination.

Event Programming
Our 2016 programming consists of a curated series of quarterly solo & group exhibitions. A total of four shows will be hosted throughout the year; each of which will stay up for a duration of a week and a half. Scheduling encompasses an opening night, a film screening and an artist talk/panel discussion tackling central issues related to each show. Artwork will be for sale.

Space
The Pendulum Project will be hosted at Studio 223A: a bright, naturally lit studio/gallery space located in the heart of Kensington Market. 

What We Need

We're looking to raise $4000 (CAD) for The Pendulum Project. It may not sound like much, but these means will be evenly distributed throughout the year to cover the cost of four feature exhibitions and respective panel discussions and film screenings.

Funding will be going towards:

  • Studio + Installation Fees (maintenance, licensing, artwork/event insurance)
  • Production (materials, printing, framing)
  • Staff Fees (because we believe in recognizing the dedication, hours and energy that artists put into creating and sharing their work)
BONUS: We are also applying to a handful of micro-grants directed towards youth-led initiatives in the city. Given the possibility of raising more than our initial budget, the funds will be put into a publication at the end of the year. This publication will be a bound collection of the four feature exhibition catalogues as well as event/installation photos and interviews with a variety of Toronto-based emerging artists. 

The Impact

We not only believe in using art as a tool for education and inspiration but also as a means to expand communication and provoke meaningful conversation within an interactive space of creativity. You can check out the full programming here
  • Art Exhibitions
  • Panel Discussions
  • Film Screenings
Studio 223A has hosted a handful of art & music happenings in the past and program director Alexia Bréard-Anderson (Lexiquette) also has a few curated exhibitions and pop-up events under her belt: the most recent one being for Toronto-based charity organization Women in Music & Arts in support of survivors of rape culture and domestic violence.

Risks & Challenges

Accessibility

We are working hard towards coming up with alternative modes of exhibiting seeing as Studio 223A is unfortunately not a wheelchair accessible space. We would like to integrate visitors with mobility difficulties and hope to make The Pendulum Project safe and inclusive for as many people as possible. 
Time Management
Many of us are full-time/part-time students and/or employees which means we have to put a lot of thought into organizing our schedules when it comes to including freelance gigs. We have worked our fair share of unpaid creative gigs and your support will take a weight off of our shoulder and help dissolve that worry of 'wasting time' or not earning enough. Because we believe in paying our staff!
Although these risks and challenges are present, we understand them as two - of many- obstacles to be overcome in our mission to bring people together through art.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are a creative DIY generation which usually means we're juggling a handful of gigs to make ends meet, so we completely understand if donating isn't something that makes sense for you right now. However, you can help us get the word out and MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN through word of mouth, social media platforms and using the Indiegogo share tools. Connected voices go far!

Thank you for your much-needed and much appreciated support.

Let's do this!

Scheduling encompasses an opening night, a film screening and an artist talk/panel discussion tackling central issues related to each show. Artwork will be for sale.SpaceThe Pendulum Project will be hosted at Studio 223A: a bright, naturally lit studio/gallery space located in the heart of Kensington Market.   

What We Need We're looking to raise $4000 (CAD) for The Pendulum Project. It may not sound like much, but these means will be evenly distributed throughout the year to cover the cost of four feature exhibitions and respective panel discussions and film screenings.
Funding will be going towards:

Studio + Installation Fees (maintenance, licensing, artwork/event insurance)
Production (materials, printing, framing)
Staff Fees (because we believe in recognizing the dedication, hours and energy that artists put into creating and sharing their work) 

BONUS: We are also applying to a handful of micro-grants directed towards youth-led initiatives in the city. Given the possibility of raising more than our initial budget, the funds will be put into a publication at the end of the year. This publication will be a bound collection of the four feature exhibition catalogues as well as event/installation photos and interviews with a variety of Toronto-based emerging artists.    

The ImpactWe not only believe in using art as a tool for education and inspiration but also as a means to expand communication and provoke meaningful conversation within an interactive space of creativity. You can check out the full programming here


Art Exhibitions
Panel Discussions
Film Screenings 
Studio 223A has hosted a handful of art & music happenings in the past and program director Alexia Bréard-Anderson (Lexiquette) also has a few curated exhibitions and pop-up events under her belt: the most recent one being for Toronto-based charity organization Women in Music & Arts in support of survivors of rape culture and domestic violence.   


Risks & Challenges

Accessibility

We are working hard towards coming up with alternative modes of exhibiting seeing as Studio 223A is unfortunately not a wheelchair accessible space. We would like to integrate visitors with mobility difficulties and hope to make The Pendulum Project safe and inclusive for as many people as possible. 
Time Management
Many of us are full-time/part-time students and/or employees which means we have to put a lot of thought into organizing our schedules when it comes to including freelance gigs. We have worked our fair share of unpaid creative gigs and your support will take a weight off of our shoulder and help dissolve that worry of 'wasting time' or not earning enough. Because we believe in paying our staff!
Although these risks and challenges are present, we understand them as two - of many- obstacles to be overcome in our mission to bring people together through art.



Other Ways You Can Help
 We are a creative DIY generation which usually means we're juggling a handful of gigs to make ends meet, so we completely understand if donating isn't something that makes sense for you right now. However, you can help us get the word out and MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN through word of mouth, social media platforms and using the Indiegogo share tools. Connected voices go far!
Thank you for your much-needed and much appreciated support.
Let's do this!

story:
Can you imagine…??

An ethically-produced line of clothing and a line of coloring books that stimulate your meditative reflection and creative side? Imagine further the Color Me Free™ line ALSO supports conscious action in empowering others to move beyond financial poverty, as well as supporting endangered species projects around our planet.

YES you Can!!

Your imagination turning into action can make it happen...

All we (and the world) need is a little boost…

Our story begins with a few artistically oriented entrepreneurs who wished to make a line of ethically-produced) clothing that would spark individual creativity, while truly making a difference for the Earth.

This project began by our love for the planet and the survival of the sentient beings that populate her. As artists, we searched for a way for people to truly give more of themselves from the heart while purchasing beautiful products, while helping to protect endangered species around the globe and empower underprivileged people, both here in the US and in underdeveloped countries.

We have created coloring books and art to wear clothing from the idea of the tremendously popular coloring books for adults. The clothing focuses on a coloring book design of an endangered species that you can color yourself, creating your very own individual wearable art. The clothing and the books, both educate about the most critically endangered species and how we, collectively and individually can help turn the loss of any species around as proceeds are given back to help protect endangered species around the globe. The Earth is a closed system and the waste we produce does not disappear, it only builds up. Whether by toxicity, poaching or loss of habitat it only takes a few species disappearing to collapse the perfect balance that ultimately allows us, humans, to be hosted upon this fragile Earth. We must begin to live in harmony.

This project is part of the growing campaign in the ethical fashion movement by offering both 100% organic clothing made entirely in the US, as well as Micromodal clothing sewn by women in underdeveloped communities empowering them to create a new paradigm of financial independence.

Details...details...details...

We have chosen to carry both Organic Cotton T-shirts, made here in the US, as well as our own personal line made of natural Micromodal (European Birch tree fiber) fabric from Turkey.

Natural fibers such as bamboo, rayon and Micromodal are organic only from the start. Though the material is labeled “organic” because the original plant was organically grown, the fiber itself, in actuality, is not. Solvents are used to dissolve the cellulose dur?ng the spinning process in order to create yarn. We prefer truth in advertising as the process used to break these fibers down are a non-organic process. Though we legally can, like many do, call it organic, we will not.

While our organic cotton t-shirts are "all USA", including the sewing, our line of Micromodal Tees will be sewn in a developing country by women supporting their families. We will insure that the work conditions are neither physically nor financially abusive to the workers. We are one world and to help a neighbor, be it next door or the next country, is to help humans all over the planet to live happier, healthier and kinder lives. We have chosen to empower women both in the US as well as women in other nations.

By purchasing a Color Me Free™ product, you can not only buy an ethical product that bears your final creativity, you can also help others be kinder to their fellow beings on this planet, be it the abandoned dog or cat or the endangered species we are losing daily at an alarming rate. Much of the devastation of our environment is from people simply trying to survive. You can take pressure off of the environment by supporting them in more productive and lucrative ways as well as educating them in the fact that destroying our environment is ultimately destroying the human race.

Every purchase you make from the "Color Me Free™" line is empowering underprivileged individuals here and abroad and sending money directly to help endangered species around the globe. Unlike most companies which give, on average, 10% of their profits to similar projects, we will be donating a minimum of 25% of our profits to one or more specific endangered species projects. To us that felt fairer. We hope you agree and participate.

What We Need & What You Get  

*Our time to finish the work of the illustrations of 40 endangered species done in the Zentangle tradition for production of the coloring book.

*Printing costs of the coloring book as well as advertising and distribution.

*A full website for the Color Me Free line of art prints, coloring books and t-shirts.

*Research and travel for overseeing production of the clothing line as well as advertising and distribution.

*Production of a line of Micromodal T-Shirts, which includes, samples, patterns, fabric and full fabrication and printing with the Zentangle designs of endangered species.

*For your donation to get this project off of the ground you will receive gifts in the way of Endangered Species prints, coloring books, organic t-shirts and coloring sets  to create your own personal masterpiece as well as personal illustrations, depending on the package you choose. 

The Impact...

You are helping us to create a vehicle for change for both humans and animals. By donating to this campaign you are helping us put products out there that are not only beautiful but fun and educational. You are helping consumers to consciously support this planet and her inhabitants in ways that those on the frontline will receive the funds they need to educate and help communities in order to keep these beautiful animals alive. It is the grass root projects that truly make the biggest impact because their hearts, like yours, are focused on their goal, not their pocket book. It is these projects that we will be funding with at least 25% of our profits from future sales. Our goal is to reach even higher toward a 50% donation margin in the future.

Most Importantly... 

Even if you cannot donate at this time, please help us get the word out. Tweet, Post and Share! 
Thank you for taking the time and contributing in any way to our heartfelt project. We greatly appreciate it!

It is these projects that we will be funding with at least 25% of our profits from future sales. Our goal is to reach even higher toward a 50% donation margin in the future.




Most Importantly... Even if you cannot donate at this time, please help us get the word out. Tweet, Post and Share! Thank you for taking the time and contributing in any way to our heartfelt project. We greatly appreciate it!

story:
"We believe that when women work together, we can accomplish great things, but when a woman's passion and drive is partnered with artistic endeavors AND each other, we can conquer the world."

Through your generosity, femme. collective will be able to continue to provide a platform for Philadelphia female artists to showcase their work. Join us!

femme. collective is asking YOU to help fund our debut showcase at The Performance Garage on February 12th and 13th, 2016. Your generosity will help us pay for space rental and stipends for all of our featured artists.

Through your sponsorship, femme. collective will be able to use the profits from this showcase to pay for ongoing events throughout the year and become a platform for female artists to utilize and showcase their work.

cherchez la femme is a showcase presented by a cast of women featuring a main-stage dance performance as well as poetry reading, an art installation, and locally sourced refreshments.

The showcase achieves a landscaped array of movement and intention by the eclectic group of artists setting work. Fluid and introspective contemporary effortlessly transcends into dark theatrics, and feats of great athleticism.

Artists that will be represented include: Keila Cordova, Devon Lutz, Amy Saul-Zerby, Caroline O’Brien, Michelle MeGill, Candace Eaton, Krista Bacchieri, Julie Marinucci, Julia Hayward, Laura Baehr, Grace Gamble, and Loren McFalls.

www.femmecollectivephilly.com

info@femmecollectivephilly.com

@femme.collective_philly

story:
The Blackmist group is proud to present the corporation game and comic book to coincide with the movie called The Blackmist Group aka The Corporation. We believe that student loan debt has become a problem in the United States and here's one way of paying off your debt.

The show itself is in development, but there are so many new and upcoming web series out there, we decided to take it to the next level to beat out the competition. In building out this world, we have a 6 issue comic book series and a mobile app game coming out for the Corporation. For the shoot itself, the fellow actresses and I are trained in martial arts for the fight scenes in this series and we have a very talented crew working alongside us.The comic book is outlined and awaiting penciling of the panels, here is the cover of the first issue!

What we love to do is share our passion and our projects with people. And that is where you come in. We are looking to raise $25,000 in help with development and getting fans in on the ground floor. Through this you will be able to get special access to the project, comic book prints, and even special codes for the mobile app game.  

 

The mobile game is what is going to really make this world pop! Full of upgrades, battles, and spy tech, play as a student and rise to the rank of Assassin. Preliminary artwork below of levels, character designs, and more!


Character 360 of the lead female avatar.

Enemies that you will encounter in the game: Bruiser, a heavy militant class, and Infiltrator, an agile spy class.

Some test renders of the game showcasing two areas: Warehouse and Mob Boss Hotel.

But helping support this project, you will also get updates with the Corporation Movie that is in development. Get excited to see this trifecta of film, print, and digital come together to tell this story!

What would you do pay off your debt?


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $25,000.00 to cover our 6 issue comic book and finish programming on our Mobile Game
  • We will give you a signed comic book, tee-shirt, cap, and poster when you donate towards our project for the corporation.
  • The funds will go to cover the video game artist, the comic book artist and the sizzle reel for the movie coming out!

The Impact

  • Right now Student Debt has become a problem and the only way we thought to be light to the subject was to make a parody about the problem.
  • Many families are in default of student loans because of the alarming rate of tuitions and by doing a parody of what really is happening could bring light that our government must allow ways to forgive student loan debt or wipe away the interest to the loans taken out.
  • This show takes a spin on the lengths students wish they could go to pay off their massive debt.

Risks & Challenges

  • Today making a show is not enough to stand out in the crowd. That is why we are pairing a 6 issue comic book and mobile game about the characters and the history of The BlackMist Group

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute reach out to friends and family and let them know about our campaign for the corporation.
  • Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools to promote our campaign!

story:
My name is Allie, I am from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and have been tattooing for 6 years. I specialize in watercolor, illustrative, and realistic tattoos. I am  a proud mother to a son born on July 10, 2016.   


   

Finding out that I was pregnant has made me put my life and career into a new perspective. An amazing opportunity fell into my lap  with a storefront opening up less than a block from my home! This will be the absolute best thing for me to continue to make my clients my priority, as well as having flexibility to raise my son. 

      

In addition, I will have the opportunity to provide a shared artist space for people involved in other art mediums to be able to benefit from the space and awesome location. This has always been a dream of mine and a very important aspect of being an artist, I believe. Tattooing is just one small piece to this puzzle, and once I am able to get this storefront remodeled, I hope to be able to provide space for artists of various mediums, gallery space, and boutique consignment. 

Your investment will allow me to be able to remodel my entire rental space, buy equipment, and craft a storefront sign. I am asking for 10,000 because the space I am remodeling is old and has not been well-kept over the years. I believe with a little love and elbow grease this space can be both beautiful and accommodating to artists and our clients.

Contributions specifically will go toward building a new floor, new bathroom, new ceiling, paint, storefront sign, furniture, and a new office.  
Each contributor will have an exclusive invitation to an opening party at the shop. I am also designing a small batch single pressing of unique art prints that will be signed and numbered. These will be given away only for this campaign. Contributions over $50 will allow you to also receive a percentage off of a tattoo upon the shop opening.
If I do not reach my goal, I will have to greatly scale back on the amount of renovating that I do and work on remodeling after the shop is open and running. Which will prove to be a bit more difficult once we are moved in and operating.
This project is valuable to the greater Pittsburgh community and to all communities. I believe it will serve as an example for other storefronts to be able to take more of a cooperative approach to shared artist space. Your contribution will help ensure the success of many local artists for years to come, and will serve as an investment into the greater arts and community.
I have helped manage 2 shops that I have worked in so far, and have plenty of experience with basic carpentry and renovation skills. This makes me confident that I can both manage a new business and build it from the ground up with my own two hands.
I feel qualified to overcome the hurdles of a starting a new business because I have the support of an amazing clientele that I have built up over the years, and a network of wonderful local artists to pull from. I recognize that it may sound foolhardy to some to be opening a shop with a child on the way, but I believe in the power of will.  My desire to make a good life for my child has given me ten times the energy, courage, and passion that I had before.
If you are unable to make a contribution, please share my campaign on your social media pages, leave us a comment, or share us with your friends! You can use the Indiegogo share tools on this site or by going to http://www.buildravenwood.com/.  Remember the more eyes that see us, the more chances we get funded.
Also, if you yourself are an artist looking to be a part of something like this, or you know of an artist that could benefit from this shared space, please reach out to us via email!
ravenwoodcollective16@gmail.com
Thank you for taking the time to view this campaign, and thank you for believing in Ravenwood Collective!

story:
En español, pulse aquí

Help create one of the first museums of paperfolding in the world!

 

 

OrigamiHouse Colonia is the name of the upcoming museum of paperfolding in Colonia del Sacramento, Uruguay. We aim to open by September of 2016. 

 

I am raising funds to build the display components of the exhibition based on a design rendered by museum experts. This includes the furnishings (lighting system, pedestals, wall partitions, glass cases) and content production (narrative, scripts and signage). 

 

The origami community from around the world has been very supportive to this project. I have been receiving models from as far as Russia, Israel, Singapore, Spain, USA, and Brazil, to name just a few countries. Many are from well-known masters and also from young and promising "rising stars".  

And the great news is that more than 30 artists who participated in Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami, agreed to donate their work. Folding Paper was the famous, groundbreaking exhibition, that toured the USA for four years! Now these models will find a permanent home in Uruguay. 

The project has received the attention of museum planners who have been offering generous advice on exhibit design and implementation. 

With everyone's help, it will be a museum like no other. All the furnishing and content will be customized to achieve the high standards that we envision. It will be a modern, educational and fun place to visit and experience hands-on activities. 

So now it is time to put all these wonderful ideas to work. And to do that we need funding.

You can be part of this great project! You may tell your grandchildren: "I helped create one of the first museums of paperfolding in the world!"

 

Please read further to learn how you can contribute. And don't forget to spread the word among your friends! 

To donate, go to the perk column on your right-hand side, or read further for more details on what we need and how you can customize your selection if you wish. For images of the perks offered, scroll down or click  here.

For the Spanish version, click here. 

What we need 

 

The goal is to raise $27,400. If we raise less, we'll have to adapt to a lower budget. If we raise more, all the better, as we'll be able to further fund programs and activities.

  1. $20,000 towards the design exhibit, construction and installation of museum furnishings, including museum-quality lighting, pedestals, glass/acrylic cases and freestanding walls. 
  2. $3,000 will be used to finish the insulation of the outer walls and to develop a project for a humidity control system. 
  3. $2,400 will help cover the cost of transportation from New York to Uruguay for more than 30 models recently donated by artists who participated in Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami, a groundbreaking exhibition that toured the USA for four years and now will find a permanent home in Uruguay. 
  4. $2,000 for the production of hands-on activities and promotional material.  
What if we raise more than $27,400? That would be awesome, because then we can start programing the next steps:
  • Outreach community programs (e.g. going to local and regional schools and/or inviting schools to come to the museum.)
  • An artist residence program: we aim at inviting international origami artists for a period of time to develop an origami project in Colonia. 

     

    My story and how the idea took shape

     

    For several years I have been working on a project called Origami Art Museum Colonia – Museo del Plegado de Papel y Talleres, aimed at bringing the art of paperfolding (also called origami) to South America.

     

    Origami has experienced an unprecedented transformation in the second part of the 21st century. From a traditional children's pastime, it has progressed into a true art form, attracting the minds of scientists, artists and designers. New techniques have developed, leading to a vast range of styles, complexities, and subject matters. Read more about the impact of origami in science here.

    Now is the time for an Origami Museum 

    Artists have been exhibiting in galleries with great success. But these venues do not address all issues related to the preservation of this art. There is a growing concern about the need to preserve models and documents, and to show the world how origami has evolved. The only answer to these questions is a museum of paperfolding, where people of all walks of life can learn and experience the magic of folding paper and at the same time become a center for conservation and research on the history of paperfolding and its connections with other disciplines.

    I began to think about this project in 2008, inspired in part by a visit to an origami exhibition at the Parrish Museum in Southampton, NY. That evening, I was lucky to attend a sneak preview of the arward-winning documentary Between the Folds. Directed by Vanessa Gould, the film illuminated "the beauty, complexity and powerful duality of origami in the 21st century" and it was a mind-opener to me. I thought there should be a place where people could go and experience the possibilities of paperfolding. The logical answer was a museum, but there were virtually no museums of that kind in the Western world. Even the word “museum” sounded a little daunting. I was concerned that it would require deep pockets and a large structure. Unless one could manage to make it smaller: a small house may suit the needs of an origami exhibition, along with community outreach programming and workshops.

     

    At that moment I was living in the United States. Being a paperfolder for most of my life, I approached OrigamiUSA, the largest community of paperfolders in the world. Over the next few years I developed strong ties with international origami artists. I served on the Board of OrigamiUSA and became the managing editor of The Paper, its print magazine. As I began to gain confidence, I shared my vision with my paperfolder friends. With no exception, everyone encouraged me to follow my dream.

    From dream to reality
    However, the main question remained. Where? What would be the ideal location for this kind of venture? I'm a little bit of an idealist... I like to "plant seeds". What would be better than a modest place with great potential to grow? Countries like Argentina and Uruguay –where I spent my childhood years –had the ingredients I was looking for: strong tourism, local creativity, inspiring culture and breathtaking landscapes. Time and again, the vision of old memories along the banks of River Plate (Río de la Plata) crossed my mind. And one town in particular, Colonia del Sacramento, in Uruguay, seemed to qualify for my project.  

                         

    Located on the Eastern side of Río de la Plata, Colonia is a charming village lost in time. Because of its historical importance, it has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Visitors from all over the world arrive –usually taking a day trip by ferry from Buenos Aires –leaving behind the stress of the bustling city. It's like entering an old postcard. Everything is bright and beautiful, and inviting for a day of relaxation.

     

     

              


    The Museum House
    I knew that a museum of paperfolding would not be out of place there: in Colonia, there are several home museums and most are two or three rooms at best!

    So off I went to buy a decrepit house in the Historic Quarter, and in 2011 it underwent a restoration to bring it back into livable condition.      

    In the meantime, I began to acquire origami artwork. The collection began to take shape with established and up and coming artists: Victor Coeurjoly (France/Spain), Kade Chan (Hong Kong), Román Díaz (Uruguay), Tomoko Fuse (Japan), Paul Fresco (USA), Ilan Garibi (Israel), Roberto Gretter (Italy), Isa Klein (Brazil), Alexander Kurth (Germany), Ron Koh (Singapore), Goran Konjevod (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Ekaterina Lukasheva (Russia/USA), Jun Maekawa (Japan), Herman Mariano (Israel), Sejin Park (South Korea/Canada), Ángel Morollón (Spain), Peter Stein (Germany), Annarosa Ventura (Italy), Stephan Weber (Germany), Makoto Yamaguchi (Japan), and many more.

     

             

     


    Growing the art collection and historical archives
    Additionally, OrigamiUSA has contributed models created and/or folded by children from around the world, from the traveling exhibitions that OrigamiUSA organize each year under the name of “Origami by Children”.

     

    The museum of paperfolding in Colonia will also house two collections of historic significance. One is the Ligia Montoya collection of books, letters and original folded models. The other is the Gershon Legman collection of historical documents and letters from origami pioneers such as Neal Elias (USA), Robert Harbin (South Africa/UK), Gershon Legman (USA/France), David Lister (UK), Ligia Montoya (Argentina), Lillian Oppenheimer (USA), Sam Randlett (USA), George Rhoads (USA), Vicente Solórzano Sagredo (Spain/Argentina), Akira Yoshizawa (Japan), and others. The archives will be open to researchers studying the history of paperfolding. 

     

       

     

    In March, 2016, the project will receive a donation from Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami. Meher McArthur, an art historian and curator who brought Folding Paper to life, proposed some time ago to have these pieces sent to Uruguay once the exhibition was over. International Arts & Artists, the non-profit organization that produced the exhibition in the USA, agreed and has been acting as a liaison between the artists donors and the Origami House Colonia project. Among the artists from that collection whose works will find a permanent home in Colonia are: Krystyna and Wojtek Burczyk (Poland), Joel Cooper (USA), Brian Chan (USA), Erik and Martin Demaine (USA), Giang Dinh (Vietnam/USA), Christine Edison (USA), Shuki Kato (USA), Eric Gjerde (USA), Miri Golan (Israel), Tran Trung Hieu (Vietnam), Tom Hull (USA), the late Roy Iwaki (Japan/USA) (through the kindness of his relatives), Paul Jackson (UK/Israel), Ruth Kitagawa (Japan/USA), Daniel Kwan (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Linda Mihara (Japan/USA), Bernie Peyton (USA), Andrea Russo (Italy), Victoria Sedova (Russia), Heinz Strobl (Germany), Nicolas Terry (France), and Polly Verity (UK).

     

           

    Risks and Challenges

     

    While I was enjoying the sweet feeling of success, my friends interrogated me with down-to-earth questions: "How are you going to manage the museum?", they wanted to know. And I said: "It's going to be a lot of work, but I think it's doable. I settled myself in Colonia.  I live here. I guess it will be like running an atelier or a gallery. I will be in the house/museum doing what I like to do. During the day, the exhibition will be open to the public, and in the evenings and weekends there will be workshops. We'll do local and regional community outreach. The museum will keep an historical archive and will create opportunities for people to work here and do research."  

    It's a big responsibility, I know. And I am grateful to the many friends who have been supporting and believe in the idea. Reaching out to you now for funding creates an even  broader compromise. But I take on the challenge happily because at the end of the day having a little museum of paperfolding is what the tiny child who still lives in me always wanted. I've been living on this wonderful planet for more than half a century (wow!) and I feel as strong as ever and ready to start a journey for which I've been preparing myself for so many years. What I know for sure is that I won't be alone. 

     

    What else?

    I know some of you may think that this is not something that you are going to be able to visit in the short term because of the distance from your home. So why bother contributing? Although it would be great if you could come and visit it (and we hope you'll do one day!), think about this: Your contribution will help this museum become a destination for origami lovers from all over the world. And once this project is up and running, it will also become an example for others to imitate, and more museums of this kind may open in different parts of the world! 

     

    And now we say Thank You!

    Versión en español

     

    Introducción 

    OrigamiHouse Colonia es el nombre del museo del plegado del papel que estamos construyendo en Colonia del Sacramento, Uruguay. El objetivo es inaugurarlo hacia septiembre de este año. 

    Los fondos recaudados servirán para construir los componentes de la exhibición de acuerdo al proyecto diseñado por un equipo de expertos en museología. Esto incluye el equipamiento (sistema de iluminación, pedestales, paredes divisorias, cajas de vidrio) así como la producción de contenido (narrativa, guión y señalización). 

    La comunidad de origami mundial ha mostrado su apoyo decisivo a este proyecto. Hemos venido recibiendo modelos de Rusia, Israel, Singapur, España, Estados Unidos, Brasil, por nombrar unos pocos países. Hay trabajos de creadores eximios y de jóvenes talentosos. 

    El proyecto ha recibido la atención de planificadores de museos que han ofrecido su generoso asesoramiento en materia de exhibición e implementación. 

    Con la ayuda de todos, este será un museo singular. Todo el equipamiento y el contenido se harán a medida para lograr la calidad buscada. Será un lugar moderno, educativo y divertido para visitar y experimentar con actividades prácticas. 

    Este es el momento de poner en práctica todas estas maravillosas ideas y por eso estamos llevando a cabo esta recaudación. 

     

    Usted puede ser parte de un gran proyecto! Un proyecto que le permitirá decir a sus nietos: "¡Yo ayudé a crear uno de los primeros museos de plegado del papel del mundo!"

    A continuación explicaremos cómo puede contribuir. ¡No olvide difundir esta campaña entre sus conocidos! 

     

    Su generosa donación hará posible...  

     

    El objetivo es recaudar 27,400 dólares. Si no se alcanza esta cifra, habrá que adaptarse a un menor prespuesto. Si se recauda más más, podremos avanzar en la programación de actividades. (Los siguientes valores están expresados en dólares norteamericanos)

    1. $3,000  para finalizar el aislamiento de las paredes externas y para proyectar un sistema de control de humedad en los exhibidores. 
    2. $20,000 para el el diseño de la exhibición, construcción e instalación del equipamiento, incluyendo iluminación de alta calidad, pedestales, cajas de vidrio/acrílico, paredes divisiorias. 
    3. $2,400 ayudarán a cubrir los costos de transporte de Nueva York a Uruguay de más de 30 piezas recientemente donadas por artistas que participaron en la exhibición Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami, que viajó por Estados Unidos durante cuatro años y tendrán un destino final en el museo de Uruguay.   
    4. $2,000 Para la producción de material de promoción y actividades prácticas. 

    ¿Y si logramos recaudar más de 27,400 dólares? Sería genial, pues entonces podremos  comenzar a programar los siguientes pasos: 

     

    • Proyectos con la comunidad local y regional (por ejemplo ir a escuelas o invitar a los alumnos al museo)
    • Un programa de residencia de artistas: invitaremos a origamistas internacionales para que pasen un tiempo desarrollando un proyecto de origami en Colonia. 

    Mi historia y cómo se gestó esta idea

    Concebí este proyecto hace varios años con la idea de desarrollar un museo del plegado del papel en América del Sur: Origami Art Museum Colonia  – Museo del Plegado de Papel y Talleres.

    El origami ha experimentado una transformación fenomenal en la segunda mitad del siglo XX. De pasatiempo infantil, se ha convertido en un verdadero arte que atrae el interés de artistas, científicos y diseñadores por igual. Se han desarrollado técnicas, algunas muy complejas que involucran algoritmos matemáticos, y que dieron lugar a diversos estilos, complejidads y temáticas. Para leer más sobre el impacto del origami en las ciencias, pulse aquí.

     

    El momento del museo es ahora

    Numerosos artistas han exhibido en importantes galerías y museos. Pero estas instancias no contemplan a fondo las cuestiones relativas a la preservación de este arte. Hay una creciente preocupación sobre la necesidad de preservar modelos y documentos, y de mostrar al mundo lo que ya se ha hecho. La respuesta a estas cuestiones es el museo del plegado del papel, donde los visitantes tengan la oportunidad de aprender y experimentar y desde el cual se consolide un centro de conservación e investigación de la historia del plegado del papel y sus conexiones con otras disciplinas.

     

    Comencé con la idea del museo en el año 2008, a partir de una exhibición que vi en el Parrish Museum de Southampton, New York. Esa tarde, además, tuve la suerte de ver el anticipo del documental  Between the Folds (que luego recibiría muchos premios). Dirigido por Vanessa Gould, la película iluminaba "la belleza, complejidad y poderosa dualidad del origami en el siglo XXI", y eso fue lo que literalmente me abrió la cabeza. Pensé que debería haber un lugar donde la gente pudiera tener una experiencia de este tipo. Lo lógico era un museo, pero no había ninguno en Occidente. Incluso la palabra "museo" suena algo temeraria. Pensé que sería necesario muchísimo dinero para armar una gran estructura. A menos que se hiciera algo más pequeño: una casa podría servir para exhibir modelos de origami, a lo que se podrían agregar programas y talleres para la comunidad. 

    En ese entonces aún vivía en los Estados Unidos. Como siempre me interesó el origami, me acerqué a  OrigamiUSA, la mayor comunidad de plegadores del mundo. Me conecté con artistas y formé parte del directorio de OrigamiUSA, además de ser actualmente la editora de su revista impresa, The Paper. Mis amigos y colegas me alentaron a seguir con mi sueño. 

    De la idea a la realidad

    La gran pregunta seguía pendiente. ¿Dónde?  ¿Cuál era el lugar ideal para llevar adelante este emprendimiento? Soy un poco idealista, me gusta "plantar semillas". Pensé que la mejor manera de hacerlo sería en un lugar que no tuviese tantos recursos económicos, pero sí, en cambio, un gran potencial para establecer un museo del plegado del papel. Países como la Argentina y el Uruguay, donde pasé mi infancia y juventud, tenían los ingredientes que estaba buscando: un fuerte turismo, creatividad local, cultura vibrante y hermosos paisajes. Una y otra vez volvía el recuerdo de la costa oriental del Río de la Plata. Y una ciudad en particular, Colonia del Sacramento, en Uruguay, me pareció perfecta para este proyecto.         

     

                    

    Ubicada en la margen oriental del Río de la Plata, Colonia es una ciudad perdida en el tiempo. Debido a su importancia histórica, ha sido declarada Patrimonio Mundial por la UNESCO. Miles de turistas llegan de todas partes del mundo, por lo general tomando un ferry desde Buenos Aires, dejando atrás el stress de la ciudad. Es como entrar en una postal antigua. Todo es brillante y hermoso e invita a descansar. 

                    

    La casa/museo

    En Colonia hay varios museos montados en casas antiguas de dos o tres habitaciones, de modo que un pequeño museo de origami estaría en la escala de lo que la ciudad ofrece. Fue así como en el año 2011 decidí comprar una vieja casona en el Barrio Histórico con la idea de refaccionarla para mi proyecto. 

      

    Así también fui coleccionando piezas de origami. Entre ellas, obras de: Victor Coeurjoly (Francia/España), Kade Chan (Hong Kong), Román Díaz (Uruguay), Tomoko Fuse (Japón), Paul Fresco (USA), Ilan Garibi (Israel), Roberto Gretter (Italia), Isa Klein (Brasil), Alexander Kurth (Alemania), Ron Koh (Singapur), Goran Konjevod (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Ekaterina Lukasheva (Rusia/USA), Jun Maekawa (Japón), Herman Mariano (Israel), Sejin Park (Corea del Sur/Canada), Ángel Morollón (España), Peter Stein (Alemania), Annarosa Ventura (Italia), Stephan Weber (Alemania), Makoto Yamaguchi (Japón), y otros.
    .

                    

    Colección de obras y archivo histórico

    OrigamiUSA contribuyó con modelos creados o plegados por niños de diversos países. Las piezas formaron parte de la conocida exhibición itinerante, llamada "Origami by Children", que organiza todos los años esta institución. 

    El museo de Colonia también alojará dos colecciones de importancia histórica. Una es la colección Ligia Montoya de libros, cartas y plegados originales que perteneció a la mencionada origamista argentina fallecida en 1967. La otra es el archivo de Gershon Legman, de documentos y cartas de pioneros del origami, como Neal Elias (USA), Robert Harbin (Inglaterra), Gershon Legman (USA/Francia), David Lister (UK), Ligia Montoya (Argentina), Lillian Oppenheimer (USA), Sam Randlett (USA), George Rhoads (USA), Vicente Solórzano Sagredo (España/Argentina), Akira Yoshizawa (Japón) y otros. El archivo estará disponible para los investigadores de la historia del plegado del papel. 

              

    En marzo de este año, recibiremos medio centenar de obras creadas por algunos de los más reconocidos origamistas del mundo. Estas piezas pertenecen a la exposición itinerante Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami,  que viajó por Estados Unidos durante cuatro años. Su curadora, Meher McArthur, tuvo la generosa idea de proponer que, una vez terminada la exhibición itinerante en Estados Unidos, las piezas viajaran a Uruguay para darles allí una residencia permanente en el museo de Colonia. International Arts & Artists, la organización sin fines de lucro que produjo esta exposición en Estados Unidos, actuó como intermediaria entre los artistas donantes y el proyecto OrigamiHouse. Entre los artistas que aceptaron donar sus trabajos figuran: Krystyna and Wojtek Burczyk (Polonia), Joel Cooper (USA), Brian Chan (USA), Erik and Martin Demaine (USA), Giang Dinh (Vietnam/USA), Christine Edison (USA), Shuki Kato (USA), Eric Gjerde (USA), Miri Golan (Israel), Tran Trung Hieu (Vietnam), Tom Hull (USA), the late Roy Iwaki (Japón/USA) (gracias a la generosa colaboración de parientes), Paul Jackson (Inglaterra/Israel), Ruth Kitagawa (Japón/USA), Daniel Kwan (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Linda Mihara (Japón/USA), Bernie Peyton (USA), Andrea Russo (Italia), Victoria Sedova (Rusia), Heinz Strobl (Alemania), Nicolas Terry (Francia), and Polly Verity (Inglaterra).

     

                   

    Riesgos y desafíos

    Mientras me entusiasmaba cada vez más con mi idea, mis amigos me hacían preguntas críticas: "¿Y cómo lo vas a manejar?", querían saber. Mi respuesta fue la siguiente: "Va a ser mucho trabajo, sin duda. Yo ya estoy establecida en Colonia. Vivo aquí. Pienso que será como llevar adelante un atelier o una galería. Durante el día, la exhibición estará abierta al público y por las tardes y fines de semana habrá talleres. Trabajaremos con la comunidad local y regional. El museo mantendrá un archivo histórico y se crearán oportunidades para hacer investigación". 

    Es una gran responsabilidad. Y estoy agradecida a los amigos que me han apoyado hasta aquí. Ahora, la solicitud de apoyo económico crea un nuevo y mayor compromiso. Pero estoy dispuesta a asumirlo pues, en última instancia, siento que le estoy dando el gusto a la pequeña niña que aún habita en mi, y que siempre soñó con un museo de papel. He vivido en este mundo durante más de medio siglo (uf!) y me siento más fuerte que nunca y lista para emprender esta nueva aventura para la que me preparé durante muchos años. De lo que estoy segura es que no estaré sola. 

     

    ¿Qué más? 

    Algunos pensarán que este museo queda muy lejos y no se justifica aportar dinero para esta causa. Es comprensible, y aunque me gustaría que todos puedan visitarlo algún día (ojalá!), creo que también es importante pensar que su contribución ayudará a que el museo se convierta en un destino ineludible para todos los amantes del origami. Además, un proyecto de esta naturaleza servirá de ejemplo a imitar para que en otras partes del mundo se creen museos de este tipo. 

     

    Y ahora: gracias!

     

     

    A continuación figura el listado de montos y recompensas. Para donar, por favor suba por esta página hasta encontrar a su derecha una columna donde podrá elegir el monto a donar. También podrá elegir donar dinero sin recibir recompensa (de este modo casi el 100% de su donación será utilizado en el proyecto OrigamiHouse Colonia). 

    Los valores están expresados en dólares norteamericanos.

    $15 A Good Luck Friend (El amigo de la suerte). En Japón, cuna del origami, la rana es símbolo de buena suerte. En Sud América, la rana precolombina representa la abundancia y prosperidad. Esta simpática ranita (1,5 pulgadas) está hecha con madera perfumada de palo santo (Bulnesia sarmientoi). Viene en una bolsita de yute con el logo del museo. El precio es por unidad. Elija más para sus amigos! 

                  

     

     

    $25 CINCO MODELOS EN TUS MANOS El CP para rinoceronte de Seth Friedman, los fotogramas de Román Díaz para el mono, el CP de Beth Johnson para su gorila, video para la orca de Hoang Tien Quyet y diagramas para su paloma! Seth Friedman, Román Díaz, Beth Johnson y Hoang Tien Quyet crearon estos modelos especialmente para nuestra campaña. Seth Friedman creó el CP para su rinoceronte (aún no tenemos la foto); Román Díaz, los fotogramas para la cara del mono; y Beth Johnson hizo un gorila y diseñó un CP fácil para principiantes.     $65 "The Little Clown" Poster realizado Giang Dinh + Instrucciones para el libro acordeón de Dennis Walker + Plegadora de madera
