story_txt:
En español, pulse  aquíHelp create one of the first museums of paperfolding in the world!
 
 
OrigamiHouse Colonia is the name of the upcoming museum of paperfolding in Colonia del Sacramento, Uruguay. We aim to open by September of 2016. 
 
I am raising funds to build the display components of the exhibition based on a design rendered by museum experts. This includes the furnishings (lighting system, pedestals, wall partitions, glass cases) and content production (narrative, scripts and signage). 
 
The origami community from around the world has been very supportive to this project. I have been receiving models from as far as Russia, Israel, Singapore, Spain, USA, and Brazil, to name just a few countries. Many are from well-known masters and also from young and promising "rising stars".  
And the great news is that more than 30 artists who participated in Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami, agreed to donate their work. Folding Paper was the famous, groundbreaking exhibition, that toured the USA for four years! Now these models will find a permanent home in Uruguay. 
The project has received the attention of museum planners who have been offering generous advice on exhibit design and implementation. 
With everyone's help, it will be a museum like no other. All the furnishing and content will be customized to achieve the high standards that we envision. It will be a modern, educational and fun place to visit and experience hands-on activities. 
So now it is time to put all these wonderful ideas to work. And to do that we need funding.
You can be part of this great project! You may tell your grandchildren: "I helped create one of the first museums of paperfolding in the world!"
 
Please read further to learn how you can contribute. And don't forget to spread the word among your friends! 
To donate, go to the perk column on your right-hand side, or read further for more details on what we need and how you can customize your selection if you wish. For images of the perks offered, scroll down or click  here.
For the Spanish version, click here. 
What we need 

 
The goal is to raise $27,400. If we raise less, we'll have to adapt to a lower budget. If we raise more, all the better, as we'll be able to further fund programs and activities.


$20,000 towards the design exhibit, construction and installation of museum furnishings, including museum-quality lighting, pedestals, glass/acrylic cases and freestanding walls. 

$3,000 will be used to finish the insulation of the outer walls and to develop a project for a humidity control system. 

$2,400 will help cover the cost of transportation from New York to Uruguay for more than 30 models recently donated by artists who participated in Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami, a groundbreaking exhibition that toured the USA for four years and now will find a permanent home in Uruguay. 

$2,000 for the production of hands-on activities and promotional material.  

What if we raise more than $27,400? That would be awesome, because then we can start programing the next steps:

Outreach community programs (e.g. going to local and regional schools and/or inviting schools to come to the museum.)
An artist residence program: we aim at inviting international origami artists for a period of time to develop an origami project in Colonia. 



 
My story and how the idea took shape
 
For several years I have been working on a project called Origami Art Museum Colonia – Museo del Plegado de Papel y Talleres, aimed at bringing the art of paperfolding (also called origami) to South America.
 
Origami has experienced an unprecedented transformation in the second part of the 21st century. From a traditional children's pastime, it has progressed into a true art form, attracting the minds of scientists, artists and designers. New techniques have developed, leading to a vast range of styles, complexities, and subject matters. Read more about the impact of origami in science here.
Now is the time for an Origami Museum 
Artists have been exhibiting in galleries with great success. But these venues do not address all issues related to the preservation of this art. There is a growing concern about the need to preserve models and documents, and to show the world how origami has evolved. The only answer to these questions is a museum of paperfolding, where people of all walks of life can learn and experience the magic of folding paper and at the same time become a center for conservation and research on the history of paperfolding and its connections with other disciplines.
I began to think about this project in 2008, inspired in part by a visit to an origami exhibition at the Parrish Museum in Southampton, NY. That evening, I was lucky to attend a sneak preview of the arward-winning documentary Between the Folds. Directed by Vanessa Gould, the film illuminated "the beauty, complexity and powerful duality of origami in the 21st century" and it was a mind-opener to me. I thought there should be a place where people could go and experience the possibilities of paperfolding. The logical answer was a museum, but there were virtually no museums of that kind in the Western world. Even the word “museum” sounded a little daunting. I was concerned that it would require deep pockets and a large structure. Unless one could manage to make it smaller: a small house may suit the needs of an origami exhibition, along with community outreach programming and workshops.
 
At that moment I was living in the United States. Being a paperfolder for most of my life, I approached OrigamiUSA, the largest community of paperfolders in the world. Over the next few years I developed strong ties with international origami artists. I served on the Board of OrigamiUSA and became the managing editor of The Paper, its print magazine. As I began to gain confidence, I shared my vision with my paperfolder friends. With no exception, everyone encouraged me to follow my dream.

From dream to realityHowever, the main question remained. Where? What would be the ideal location for this kind of venture? I'm a little bit of an idealist... I like to "plant seeds". What would be better than a modest place with great potential to grow? Countries like Argentina and Uruguay –where I spent my childhood years –had the ingredients I was looking for: strong tourism, local creativity, inspiring culture and breathtaking landscapes. Time and again, the vision of old memories along the banks of River Plate (Río de la Plata) crossed my mind. And one town in particular, Colonia del Sacramento, in Uruguay, seemed to qualify for my project.  


                     

Located on the Eastern side of Río de la Plata, Colonia is a charming village lost in time. Because of its historical importance, it has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Visitors from all over the world arrive –usually taking a day trip by ferry from Buenos Aires –leaving behind the stress of the bustling city. It's like entering an old postcard. Everything is bright and beautiful, and inviting for a day of relaxation.
 
 
          
The Museum HouseI knew that a museum of paperfolding would not be out of place there: in Colonia, there are several home museums and most are two or three rooms at best!
So off I went to buy a decrepit house in the Historic Quarter, and in 2011 it underwent a restoration to bring it back into livable condition.      In the meantime, I began to acquire origami artwork. The collection began to take shape with established and up and coming artists: Victor Coeurjoly (France/Spain), Kade Chan (Hong Kong), Román Díaz (Uruguay), Tomoko Fuse (Japan), Paul Fresco (USA), Ilan Garibi (Israel), Roberto Gretter (Italy), Isa Klein (Brazil), Alexander Kurth (Germany), Ron Koh (Singapore), Goran Konjevod (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Ekaterina Lukasheva (Russia/USA), Jun Maekawa (Japan), Herman Mariano (Israel), Sejin Park (South Korea/Canada), Ángel Morollón (Spain), Peter Stein (Germany), Annarosa Ventura (Italy), Stephan Weber (Germany), Makoto Yamaguchi (Japan), and many more.
 
         
 

Growing the art collection and historical archivesAdditionally, OrigamiUSA has contributed models created and/or folded by children from around the world, from the traveling exhibitions that OrigamiUSA organize each year under the name of “Origami by Children”.

 
The museum of paperfolding in Colonia will also house two collections of historic significance. One is the Ligia Montoya collection of books, letters and original folded models. The other is the Gershon Legman collection of historical documents and letters from origami pioneers such as Neal Elias (USA), Robert Harbin (South Africa/UK), Gershon Legman (USA/France), David Lister (UK), Ligia Montoya (Argentina), Lillian Oppenheimer (USA), Sam Randlett (USA), George Rhoads (USA), Vicente Solórzano Sagredo (Spain/Argentina), Akira Yoshizawa (Japan), and others. The archives will be open to researchers studying the history of paperfolding. 
 
   
 
In March, 2016, the project will receive a donation from Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami. Meher McArthur, an art historian and curator who brought Folding Paper to life, proposed some time ago to have these pieces sent to Uruguay once the exhibition was over. International Arts & Artists, the non-profit organization that produced the exhibition in the USA, agreed and has been acting as a liaison between the artists donors and the Origami House Colonia project. Among the artists from that collection whose works will find a permanent home in Colonia are: Krystyna and Wojtek Burczyk (Poland), Joel Cooper (USA), Brian Chan (USA), Erik and Martin Demaine (USA), Giang Dinh (Vietnam/USA), Christine Edison (USA), Shuki Kato (USA), Eric Gjerde (USA), Miri Golan (Israel), Tran Trung Hieu (Vietnam), Tom Hull (USA), the late Roy Iwaki (Japan/USA) (through the kindness of his relatives), Paul Jackson (UK/Israel), Ruth Kitagawa (Japan/USA), Daniel Kwan (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Linda Mihara (Japan/USA), Bernie Peyton (USA), Andrea Russo (Italy), Victoria Sedova (Russia), Heinz Strobl (Germany), Nicolas Terry (France), and Polly Verity (UK).
 
       

Risks and Challenges
 
While I was enjoying the sweet feeling of success, my friends interrogated me with down-to-earth questions: "How are you going to manage the museum?", they wanted to know. And I said: "It's going to be a lot of work, but I think it's doable. I settled myself in Colonia.  I live here. I guess it will be like running an atelier or a gallery. I will be in the house/museum doing what I like to do. During the day, the exhibition will be open to the public, and in the evenings and weekends there will be workshops. We'll do local and regional community outreach. The museum will keep an historical archive and will create opportunities for people to work here and do research."  
It's a big responsibility, I know. And I am grateful to the many friends who have been supporting and believe in the idea. Reaching out to you now for funding creates an even  broader compromise. But I take on the challenge happily because at the end of the day having a little museum of paperfolding is what the tiny child who still lives in me always wanted. I've been living on this wonderful planet for more than half a century (wow!) and I feel as strong as ever and ready to start a journey for which I've been preparing myself for so many years. What I know for sure is that I won't be alone. 

 
What else?I know some of you may think that this is not something that you are going to be able to visit in the short term because of the distance from your home. So why bother contributing? Although it would be great if you could come and visit it (and we hope you'll do one day!), think about this: Your contribution will help this museum become a destination for origami lovers from all over the world. And once this project is up and running, it will also become an example for others to imitate, and more museums of this kind may open in different parts of the world!  

And now we say Thank You! The following is a list of perk levels availble. To donate, check here your options and when you are done go to the right-hand column and pick up a contribution level. You also have the option to donate without selecting a reward by clicking on the "Contribute Now" pink button a the top of the column (then almost 100% of your contribution minus Indiegogo's fees will fund the project). 
 $5 OrigamiHouse Colonia Logo A virtual hug, a kiss and the first logo of Origami House Colonia sent  via email for you to treasure.                                                   $10 BREATHING LIFE INTO PAPER - HOANG TIEN QUYET'S INSTRUCTIONS FOR THE ORCA AND DOVE.  Fold like a pro with these Quyet's guidance! Get his video for the orca and a digram sheet for the dove (photos below). $15 A Good Luck Friend. In Japan, the home of origami, the frog is a symbol of good luck. In South America, the Pre-Columbian frog also represents abundance and prosperity. This little fellow (1.5") full of character is made out of scented green wood (Palo Santo, Bulnesia sarmientoi). Enclosed in a burlap bag with museum logo. $15 each. Get more for your friends to wish them happiness!       $25 Five Models at Your Fingertips - Seth Friedman's Rhinoceros Crease Pattern, Román Díaz Monkey Face step folds, Beth Johnson's CP Gorilla, Hoang Tien Quyet's Orca video and Dove diagram!!! Seth Friedman, Román Díaz, Beth Johnson and Hoang Tien Quyet are among the best origami creators today. We are thrilled and honored for their wonderful donation to this campaign. Two crease patterns, one diagram, one video, and one steps fold, will ensure hours of fun folding. You'll get them all by email when you select this perk.                                              HOANG TIEN QUYET'S ORCA (VIDEO)
                                            
 
                                        HOANG TIEN QUYET'S DOVE (DIAGRAM)
 
             
                                 ROMAN DIAZ'S MONKEY FACE (STEP FOLDS) 
                                   
 
 
 
         
                     BETH JOHNSONS'S BABY GORILLA (CREASE PATTERN)             
 
                                                                                     SETH FRIEDMAN'S RHINOCEROS (MODEL UNDER PRODUCTION) 
                                       
$25 Wood creaser + Frog You will receive one "good luck" frog and one wooden creaser with OHC logo. The a 5 3/4" long wood creaser will feel so good in your hand. Light and terse, it displays the beautiful hardwood grain of Palo Santo (Bulnesia sarmientoi). Less heavy than traditional bamboo creasers, it is virtually unbreakable. It has one side flat and one rounded to flatten, smooth, or to go inside creases with the pointed tip. With the name of Origami House Colonia engraved. If you choose more than one, please change the contribution amount accordingly. 
 
                                            
 
 
$30 Cute paperholders + Frog. Made out of hard woods, nicely polished to a lustrous finish. For your workspace or wall decoration, a spring mechanism holds paper in place. Versión en español 

Introducción 
OrigamiHouse Colonia es el nombre del museo del plegado del papel que estamos construyendo en Colonia del Sacramento, Uruguay. El objetivo es inaugurarlo hacia septiembre de este año. 
Los fondos recaudados servirán para construir los componentes de la exhibición de acuerdo al proyecto diseñado por un equipo de expertos en museología. Esto incluye el equipamiento (sistema de iluminación, pedestales, paredes divisorias, cajas de vidrio) así como la producción de contenido (narrativa, guión y señalización). 
La comunidad de origami mundial ha mostrado su apoyo decisivo a este proyecto. Hemos venido recibiendo modelos de Rusia, Israel, Singapur, España, Estados Unidos, Brasil, por nombrar unos pocos países. Hay trabajos de creadores eximios y de jóvenes talentosos. 
El proyecto ha recibido la atención de planificadores de museos que han ofrecido su generoso asesoramiento en materia de exhibición e implementación. 
Con la ayuda de todos, este será un museo singular. Todo el equipamiento y el contenido se harán a medida para lograr la calidad buscada. Será un lugar moderno, educativo y divertido para visitar y experimentar con actividades prácticas. 
Este es el momento de poner en práctica todas estas maravillosas ideas y por eso estamos llevando a cabo esta recaudación. 
 
Usted puede ser parte de un gran proyecto! Un proyecto que le permitirá decir a sus nietos: "¡Yo ayudé a crear uno de los primeros museos de plegado del papel del mundo!"
A continuación explicaremos cómo puede contribuir. ¡No olvide difundir esta campaña entre sus conocidos! 
 
Su generosa donación hará posible...  
 
El objetivo es recaudar 27,400 dólares. Si no se alcanza esta cifra, habrá que adaptarse a un menor prespuesto. Si se recauda más más, podremos avanzar en la programación de actividades. (Los siguientes valores están expresados en dólares norteamericanos)

$3,000  para finalizar el aislamiento de las paredes externas y para proyectar un sistema de control de humedad en los exhibidores. 
$20,000 para el el diseño de la exhibición, construcción e instalación del equipamiento, incluyendo iluminación de alta calidad, pedestales, cajas de vidrio/acrílico, paredes divisiorias. 
$2,400 ayudarán a cubrir los costos de transporte de Nueva York a Uruguay de más de 30 piezas recientemente donadas por artistas que participaron en la exhibición Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami, que viajó por Estados Unidos durante cuatro años y tendrán un destino final en el museo de Uruguay.   
$2,000 Para la producción de material de promoción y actividades prácticas. 

¿Y si logramos recaudar más de 27,400 dólares? Sería genial, pues entonces podremos  comenzar a programar los siguientes pasos: 
 

Proyectos con la comunidad local y regional (por ejemplo ir a escuelas o invitar a los alumnos al museo)
Un programa de residencia de artistas: invitaremos a origamistas internacionales para que pasen un tiempo desarrollando un proyecto de origami en Colonia. 

Mi historia y cómo se gestó esta idea
Concebí este proyecto hace varios años con la idea de desarrollar un museo del plegado del papel en América del Sur: Origami Art Museum Colonia  – Museo del Plegado de Papel y Talleres.
El origami ha experimentado una transformación fenomenal en la segunda mitad del siglo XX. De pasatiempo infantil, se ha convertido en un verdadero arte que atrae el interés de artistas, científicos y diseñadores por igual. Se han desarrollado técnicas, algunas muy complejas que involucran algoritmos matemáticos, y que dieron lugar a diversos estilos, complejidads y temáticas. Para leer más sobre el impacto del origami en las ciencias, pulse aquí.
 
El momento del museo es ahora
Numerosos artistas han exhibido en importantes galerías y museos. Pero estas instancias no contemplan a fondo las cuestiones relativas a la preservación de este arte. Hay una creciente preocupación sobre la necesidad de preservar modelos y documentos, y de mostrar al mundo lo que ya se ha hecho. La respuesta a estas cuestiones es el museo del plegado del papel, donde los visitantes tengan la oportunidad de aprender y experimentar y desde el cual se consolide un centro de conservación e investigación de la historia del plegado del papel y sus conexiones con otras disciplinas.
 
Comencé con la idea del museo en el año 2008, a partir de una exhibición que vi en el Parrish Museum de Southampton, New York. Esa tarde, además, tuve la suerte de ver el anticipo del documental  Between the Folds (que luego recibiría muchos premios). Dirigido por Vanessa Gould, la película iluminaba "la belleza, complejidad y poderosa dualidad del origami en el siglo XXI", y eso fue lo que literalmente me abrió la cabeza. Pensé que debería haber un lugar donde la gente pudiera tener una experiencia de este tipo. Lo lógico era un museo, pero no había ninguno en Occidente. Incluso la palabra "museo" suena algo temeraria. Pensé que sería necesario muchísimo dinero para armar una gran estructura. A menos que se hiciera algo más pequeño: una casa podría servir para exhibir modelos de origami, a lo que se podrían agregar programas y talleres para la comunidad. 
En ese entonces aún vivía en los Estados Unidos. Como siempre me interesó el origami, me acerqué a  OrigamiUSA, la mayor comunidad de plegadores del mundo. Me conecté con artistas y formé parte del directorio de OrigamiUSA, además de ser actualmente la editora de su revista impresa, The Paper. Mis amigos y colegas me alentaron a seguir con mi sueño. 
De la idea a la realidad
La gran pregunta seguía pendiente. ¿Dónde?  ¿Cuál era el lugar ideal para llevar adelante este emprendimiento? Soy un poco idealista, me gusta "plantar semillas". Pensé que la mejor manera de hacerlo sería en un lugar que no tuviese tantos recursos económicos, pero sí, en cambio, un gran potencial para establecer un museo del plegado del papel. Países como la Argentina y el Uruguay, donde pasé mi infancia y juventud, tenían los ingredientes que estaba buscando: un fuerte turismo, creatividad local, cultura vibrante y hermosos paisajes. Una y otra vez volvía el recuerdo de la costa oriental del Río de la Plata. Y una ciudad en particular, Colonia del Sacramento, en Uruguay, me pareció perfecta para este proyecto.         
 
                
Ubicada en la margen oriental del Río de la Plata, Colonia es una ciudad perdida en el tiempo. Debido a su importancia histórica, ha sido declarada Patrimonio Mundial por la UNESCO. Miles de turistas llegan de todas partes del mundo, por lo general tomando un ferry desde Buenos Aires, dejando atrás el stress de la ciudad. Es como entrar en una postal antigua. Todo es brillante y hermoso e invita a descansar. 
                
La casa/museo
En Colonia hay varios museos montados en casas antiguas de dos o tres habitaciones, de modo que un pequeño museo de origami estaría en la escala de lo que la ciudad ofrece. Fue así como en el año 2011 decidí comprar una vieja casona en el Barrio Histórico con la idea de refaccionarla para mi proyecto. 
  
Así también fui coleccionando piezas de origami. Entre ellas, obras de: Victor Coeurjoly (Francia/España), Kade Chan (Hong Kong), Román Díaz (Uruguay), Tomoko Fuse (Japón), Paul Fresco (USA), Ilan Garibi (Israel), Roberto Gretter (Italia), Isa Klein (Brasil), Alexander Kurth (Alemania), Ron Koh (Singapur), Goran Konjevod (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Ekaterina Lukasheva (Rusia/USA), Jun Maekawa (Japón), Herman Mariano (Israel), Sejin Park (Corea del Sur/Canada), Ángel Morollón (España), Peter Stein (Alemania), Annarosa Ventura (Italia), Stephan Weber (Alemania), Makoto Yamaguchi (Japón), y otros..
                
Colección de obras y archivo histórico
OrigamiUSA contribuyó con modelos creados o plegados por niños de diversos países. Las piezas formaron parte de la conocida exhibición itinerante, llamada "Origami by Children", que organiza todos los años esta institución. 
El museo de Colonia también alojará dos colecciones de importancia histórica. Una es la colección Ligia Montoya de libros, cartas y plegados originales que perteneció a la mencionada origamista argentina fallecida en 1967. La otra es el archivo de Gershon Legman, de documentos y cartas de pioneros del origami, como Neal Elias (USA), Robert Harbin (Inglaterra), Gershon Legman (USA/Francia), David Lister (UK), Ligia Montoya (Argentina), Lillian Oppenheimer (USA), Sam Randlett (USA), George Rhoads (USA), Vicente Solórzano Sagredo (España/Argentina), Akira Yoshizawa (Japón) y otros. El archivo estará disponible para los investigadores de la historia del plegado del papel. 
          
En marzo de este año, recibiremos medio centenar de obras creadas por algunos de los más reconocidos origamistas del mundo. Estas piezas pertenecen a la exposición itinerante Folding Paper, the Infinite Possibilities of Origami,  que viajó por Estados Unidos durante cuatro años. Su curadora, Meher McArthur, tuvo la generosa idea de proponer que, una vez terminada la exhibición itinerante en Estados Unidos, las piezas viajaran a Uruguay para darles allí una residencia permanente en el museo de Colonia. International Arts & Artists, la organización sin fines de lucro que produjo esta exposición en Estados Unidos, actuó como intermediaria entre los artistas donantes y el proyecto OrigamiHouse. Entre los artistas que aceptaron donar sus trabajos figuran: Krystyna and Wojtek Burczyk (Polonia), Joel Cooper (USA), Brian Chan (USA), Erik and Martin Demaine (USA), Giang Dinh (Vietnam/USA), Christine Edison (USA), Shuki Kato (USA), Eric Gjerde (USA), Miri Golan (Israel), Tran Trung Hieu (Vietnam), Tom Hull (USA), the late Roy Iwaki (Japón/USA) (gracias a la generosa colaboración de parientes), Paul Jackson (Inglaterra/Israel), Ruth Kitagawa (Japón/USA), Daniel Kwan (USA), Robert Lang (USA), Linda Mihara (Japón/USA), Bernie Peyton (USA), Andrea Russo (Italia), Victoria Sedova (Rusia), Heinz Strobl (Alemania), Nicolas Terry (Francia), and Polly Verity (Inglaterra).
 
               
Riesgos y desafíos
Mientras me entusiasmaba cada vez más con mi idea, mis amigos me hacían preguntas críticas: "¿Y cómo lo vas a manejar?", querían saber. Mi respuesta fue la siguiente: "Va a ser mucho trabajo, sin duda. Yo ya estoy establecida en Colonia. Vivo aquí. Pienso que será como llevar adelante un atelier o una galería. Durante el día, la exhibición estará abierta al público y por las tardes y fines de semana habrá talleres. Trabajaremos con la comunidad local y regional. El museo mantendrá un archivo histórico y se crearán oportunidades para hacer investigación". 
Es una gran responsabilidad. Y estoy agradecida a los amigos que me han apoyado hasta aquí. Ahora, la solicitud de apoyo económico crea un nuevo y mayor compromiso. Pero estoy dispuesta a asumirlo pues, en última instancia, siento que le estoy dando el gusto a la pequeña niña que aún habita en mi, y que siempre soñó con un museo de papel. He vivido en este mundo durante más de medio siglo (uf!) y me siento más fuerte que nunca y lista para emprender esta nueva aventura para la que me preparé durante muchos años. De lo que estoy segura es que no estaré sola. 
 
¿Qué más? 
Algunos pensarán que este museo queda muy lejos y no se justifica aportar dinero para esta causa. Es comprensible, y aunque me gustaría que todos puedan visitarlo algún día (ojalá!), creo que también es importante pensar que su contribución ayudará a que el museo se convierta en un destino ineludible para todos los amantes del origami. Además, un proyecto de esta naturaleza servirá de ejemplo a imitar para que en otras partes del mundo se creen museos de este tipo. 
 
Y ahora: gracias!

PATROCINE LA BIBLIOTECA $1500 Patrocine la Biblioteca del museo. Elija esta opción y su nombre quedará inscripto en una placa en la sala (a menos que desee hacer su donación anónima). Además, cinco noches de estadía en un apartamento en Buenos Aires; un pasaje ida y vuelta a Colonia. Visita a los lugares históricos; presentación de Origami House Colonia; almuerzo en el museo; te en Lentas Maravillas o casa de té similar; El libro con su nombre impreso, el bolso, y placa de reconocimiento en el museo y en la biblioteca. Envío gratis a todo el mundo. (Pasaje internacional no está

story:
CUE INTRODUCTORY THEREMIN MUSIC:

Hi there. My name is Christopher Barton. I'm the director of this year's Haunted Basement, and it is my sincere honor to scare the pants off each and every one of you this year.

I have a very special task - to oversee the creation of The Haunted Basement's tenth anniversary. A decade ago, this project was comprised of little more than a few flashlights, a long piece of rope, and a few creative volunteers who saw a lot of raw potential in the building's extremely eerie lower level. 

Now, it has become abundantly clear that we have created a monster. 

Each year, a growing army of artists and performers converge to bring all new nightmares to life, tasked with the knowledge that our audience holds us to a unique standard in the world of haunted attractions: We are one part installation art, one part performance art, and one part pee-your-pants slapdamn crazy. 

In addition to all the chills and screams we've inspired over the past ten years, The Haunted Basement has been influential to the performing arts. Take for example the burgeoning genre of immersive theater. Veteran Haunted Basement director Noah Bremer and Live Action Set created the Ivey Award-winning production Crime and Punishment in The Soap Factory's basement, sharing many of the same artists and techniques developed in The Haunted Basement.  Who knows where we'll creep up next?

The evolution of this project over the last decade has been a thrill ride beyond anybody's expectations. Which is why we need this milestone year to pack a bigger bang than ever.

HERE'S THE POOP:

The Haunted Basement is gearing up for a tenth anniversary party that nobody will forget. We need your donations to help us create our most integrated and intense experience yet. Here's what's new:

  • We are currently designing upper-level attractions such as a lounge, a tenth anniversary retrospective exhibition, and a screening room for a Creep movie night series. 
  • Via this very campaign, we are offering eerily exclusive experiences - want to enjoy a romantic three-course dinner with your sweetie, Haunted Basement style? Or maybe you'd like one of our resident goons to deliver a customized Creep-O-Gram to your BFF at their place of work? Check out our incentives - we're just getting started.
  • For the first time in our ten years of existence, The Haunted Basement is developing MERCH! Most notably, we are excited to introduce The Haunted Basement Tarot - 76 cards featuring original artwork by our very own artists and performers. The HBX Tarot will ONLY be available at this year's Haunted Basement or via pre-orders from this campaign.

IF WE KNEW HOW TO LOVE, WE'D LOVE YOU ALL.

Whether you throw a hefty chunk of change our way for one of our beyond-the-pale incentive experiences or are just able to give us a couple of bucks for good luck, we need you to know we value every single person who donates to this campaign, and we appreciate everyone who visits The Haunted Basement. 

Our challenge is our joy: to create the most playfully transgressive, psychologically warped, feverishly irreverent horrorscapes you'll ever see. With your support, we can blow the roof off this tenth year of ghoulish greatness.

BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE:

If you want to help us make The Haunted Basement a success this year in ways that don't involve your checking account, why not volunteer? We can always use actors, front of house staff, and a wide array of other crafty creeps. Contact us at thehauntedbasement@soapfactory.org and we'll get you started!

story:
THE CAST:

ELLERY SPRAYBERRY - Gwen | Ego | Logic


THE CREW:

Director - Tyler Winther

Director of Photography - Meinrad Hofer

Production Design - Matt Beukelman

Costume Design - Nancy Fisher

Composer - Jon O'Hara

Producer - Vivian Winther


WHAT WE NEED: $7,000.00

This is a $10,000.00 film and that's with favors.

I've already put in $3,000.00 to secure stages so we could set our shoot dates for June 10-13.

The remaining $7,000.00 will cover the following:

Grip, LED, and Sound Rental

Insurance

Crew Fee's

SAG Fee's

Building Materials

Wardrobe Rental Costs

Prop Rental Costs

Projector Rental ( Two of them)

DISTRIBUTION / EXHIBITION:

This isn't a stand alone short bound for the depths of Youtube. This is the centerpiece of an installation art experience. The hope is to have the audience experience a movie in a new way, by going through a three part process similar to that of our main character. 

Starting with a pre-screening process,  the audience members are introduced to thematic elements of the film. They then enter the viewing room, built to match the stage in the film, and experience the movie. After wards, the screen rises and they exit into an stills exhibition where they can see behind the scenes photographs and take a peek behind the curtain at what made the movie possible as well as what it looks like from a still perspective. In this space they'll also have an opportunity to think about what they just witnessed for a moment before returning back to their busy life. 

The whole viewing process has a three act structure geared towards having an audience member emerge from the screening having actually felt something. It's our hope that these feelings will spark a larger conversation about divorce, the effects it has on our relationships, and how to go about resolving or at least coping with the issues it creates between those we love or once loved. 

Risks & Challenges

Every film is a risk, that's what makes it fun. 
But our greatest challenges will be technical. We have one actress playing four roles all of which with different personalities,costume, hair, and makeup. It will be a very technical shoot utilizing a photo double and extensive light cues. It requires a lot of choreography and precision. Pulling all of this together is the only way the film will happen and it will be a great challenge. 
To meet this challenge we have an accomplished young actress and a mix of talented crew with different creative backgrounds and varying ages. The pairing of creativity and experience will pull us through.

story:
$loth (Silent Collaboration) is a lifestyle brand that stems from a series of mine titled Silent Collaboration. As an artist working with what we call "new photography," it is important to express experimentation within the art world. And with experimentation comes collaboration. 


$loth (Silent Collaboration)  is a walking talking exhibition. There will be editions. Each edition will feature the work of different artists that also believe their work is meant to be seen outside a gallery space. 
$loth (Silent Collaboration) is for my peers. The goal is to create a Platform to display YOUR work and help get recognition.  It is important for us young artists to work together, to collaborate. Let's create a new medium together!
Although the motive is almost set in stone, the brand itself is subject to change. Any thoughts, ideas, comments will be as generous as a donation!
We are going to start off with some simple formatted T-shirts featuring photographs from SILENT COLLABORATION (Caps part of title.) for the public to get a better understanding of what our brand is going to be. 
The reason for funding is to cover production costs, all other work will be completed by myself until we eventually reach out to other artists looking for this type of collaboration. 
Any comments or donations would be greatly appreciated, I must emphasize that this brand is for YOU, my wonderful young peers and artists of All mediums!

story:
Dear Friends, colleagues, and supporters,

Hello, my name is Madeleine Finley. You can see examples of my artwork at www.MadeleineFinley.com . I graduated with my BFA from The School of the Art Institute of Chicago in 2013 and will be pursuing my Master's in Painting at The School of the Art Institute this fall of 2016. Being accepted into The School of the Art Institute of Chicago for my MFA is an amazing accomplishment, I have been working the past three years to make sure I get into the best school. However, the costs have left me financially drained.

After being accepted into Graduate school, I was accepted into the Rome Art Program Summer Residency. It is a two month residency where I will be painting around the city and taking an Art History intensive course. It is a once in a life-time opportunity and will help me advance my practice in a very critical way.

I’ve created this Indiegogo campaign to give perks in exchange for your support to help me get to Rome, and make new work when I get there.


ABOUT THE RESIDENCY:

http://romeartprogram.org/

Launched in 2009, the Rome Art Program is designed to inspire students to expand their artistic vision through painting and drawing on the streets of Rome; expanding on the plein-air tradition of earlier generations of artists.

The Program is incorporated as a U.S. non-profit educational organization and it’s Artistic Director is Carole Robb, a winner of the Rome Prize in Painting (1980), a Fulbright Scholar and a member of the National Academy NY.  Ms. Robb has worked and exhibited in Rome, London, and New York.  The Program has an internationally recognized faculty of artists, visiting artists and art historians.

story:
Support Still Here IV: disPLACEment

Hello! We are Natalia and Cristina, two best friends and queer woman of color raised in San Francisco. We launched Still Here in 2013 because we didn’t see  reflection of people like us in the San Francisco Bay Area LGBTQQ arts community.

Since 2013, Still Here has become a beloved annual performance at the National Queer Arts Festival in San Francisco. In our performances, queer artists who were raised in San Francisco explore themes of love, loss, resilience, the AIDS epidemic, and the meaning of home in a “gay mecca” by presenting original work in front of sold-out audiences. The work is vulnerable, moving, and stunningly real. Check out our past shows on our Vimeo channel and a review of the 2013 show from Ms. Magazine.

In 2016, we will tackle the theme of displacement with a moving cast of artists that re-imagine and reinvent the meaning of home within our rapidly home city of San Francisco. We’ve seen first-hand how rising costs of living and evictions have impacted LGBTQQ artists and caused a widespread diaspora, even for those with deep roots in San Francisco.

We need your help to present Still Here IV: disPLACEment on June 15, 2016 at the African American Arts & Culture Complex! We have 10+ incredible artists and a crew of 5+ people that we want to support. Ticket sales and grants alone aren't enough to pay our artists and crew. As a team of two, most of our work is voluntary, but it’s critical to us that our artists, crew, and others receive generous compensation for their work.

We've created 3 years of Still Here performances without crowdfunding and this year we ask you to support us in bringing our 2016 show to life!


Why We Hella Need You & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to produce this year's show.

All money raised goes directly to support this year's queer artists and crew. 

We <3 our community and here are some perks for donating:

$25 and up = Social Media Shout-out

$50 = Social Media Shout-out + Digital Thank You Card with Still Here IV Cast Photo

$75 = Social Media Shout-out + Handwritten Thank You Card from the entire cast

$100 = Handwritten Thank You Card  + Acknowledgement in Still Here IV program

$200 = Still Here Tote Bag + Handwritten Thank You Card  + Acknowledgement in program


Still Here's Impact

In three short years  50+ artists have participated in Still Here with over 600 audience members!

Here's what  Still Here alumni artists are sayin':

"Still Here artists are the informal historians of our own version of San Francisco."

"Living in San Francisco would have been filled with so much more despair for the last 4 years without Still Here." 

"Still Here has given me hope and comfort that we will not be forgotten."

Other Ways You Can Help

Whatever you can give, we really appreciate! You can be part of supporting Still Here by doing any of these things:

  • Ask your community to support and donate. Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share this on Facebook, Twitter, Insta, your blog, email, text, or even word-of-mouth!

  • Purchase tickets to see Still Here IV: http://qcc2.org/still-here-iv/

  • RSVP for Still Here IV: Still Here IV Event Page on Facebook

  • Like Still Here (https://www.facebook.com/StillHereSanFrancisco) on Facebook

No gift is too small or too large. You can be part of preserving Still Here voices by sharing this page with other people who you think would love to support this project. Thanks for your help making some noise about our campaign and tag us using our hashtag #StillHereSF! <3

Still Here 2013 Artists

Still Here 2014 Artists

Still Here 2015 Artists

story:
I will start with a pulled reference:

Self-realization and neuroticism

An innate need for self-realization leads people to explore and integrate these disowned parts of themselves. This natural process is called individuation, or the process of becoming an individual.

According to Jung, self-realization is attained through individuation. His is an adult psychology, divided into two distinct tiers. In the first half of our lives, we separate from humanity. We attempt to create our own identities (“I”, “myself”). This is why there is such a need for young men to be destructive, and can be expressed as animosity from teens directed at their parents. Jung also said we have a sort of "second puberty" that occurs between ages 35 and 40: outlook shifts from emphasis on materialism, sexuality, and having children to concerns about community and spirituality.

In the second half of our lives, humans reunite with the human race. They become part of the collective once again. This is when adults start to contribute to humanity (volunteer time, build, garden, create art, etc.) rather than destroy. They are also more likely to pay attention to their unconscious and conscious feelings. Young men rarely say "I feel angry" or "I feel sad." This is because they have not yet rejoined the human collective experience, commonly reestablished in their older, wiser years, according to Jung. A common theme is for young rebels to "search" for their true selves and realize that a contribution to humanity is essentially a necessity for a whole self.

Jung proposes that the ultimate goal of the collective unconscious and self-realization is to pull us to the highest experience. This, of course, is spiritual.

If a person does not proceed toward self-knowledge, neurotic symptoms may arise. Symptoms are widely defined, including, for instance, phobias, psychosis, and depression.

(Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytical_psycho...)

Hello,

My name is Felice Zhukov.

You might not know me, but then again you might know me, or you might read my blog, or you might have encountered my art before.

There’s many variables here, lets just press on.

 

I am an artist, this is what I do:

 

My website.

https://felicezhukov.net

 

Instagram (specific platform only performances on here - though take heed I don’t use instagram at the moment and haven’t done for months)

https://www.instagram.com/felicezhukov/

 

Soundcloud (my first tentative steps into working with sound, now though I know what a bar is so the album is a little more advanced).

https://soundcloud.com/fep-2

 

These are all documents of my own process of individuation, which I refashion into the art I make.

 

THE PROJECT

 

I’m currently in the final stages of producing a 88 page guerilla publication and 8 track album dedicated to my ex husband, the amount asked for is far below what the real costs are, instead it is in keeping with the name of the project:  (+8% charge this site will take):

восем = 8 acht = 8 ocho = 8,

Those costs are for the last 3 months of production, including materials (paper, pens, paint, music gear), studio rent and time incurred from early planning to its distribution, in the coming months.

As an example, photocopying alone will cost in excess of €200 as I am copying 88 x 88 pages (equalling 7,744) then individually hand binding and wrapping each copy  and depositing a link inside the parcel that will go through to a private page on my soundcloud, where you will be able to download and play the album.

 

8 is infinity turned on its axis, originally inspired by a hip hop lyric and then cemented by a small sojourn through numerology, 3 8’s because everything I do seems to be guided by the rule of 3.

Infinity is forgiving as it presents the eternal, which nullifies the anxiety of small contrivances such as difficulties that present themselves in your life, when everything is framed in the vast eternal space nothing is quite so important. So despite the content of the publication and the album being so emotional and personal to me, its inception and creation have been undertaken with the understanding that it is one story among the many. 

The album takes it cues from a variation of musical influences mostly centred in the contemporary electronic scene, but inter splices distorted and layered vocals with a vein of absurdism and tragedy. Each song targets a moment in the relationship I had with my ex husband, whether it be our wedding, somewhere we lived or a holiday in Thailand. It has been created as a gift for him, as he has supported and looked after me even after the dissolution of our relationship.

The publication consists of a set of photographs lifted from my iPhone and then drawn, these were not originally taken for the purpose of using them as art and therefore act to reveal my life through the images I received and recorded from March - August 2018, this period is when I moved from the London, my home of 10+ years to Berlin. As an ensemble they depict my brief and clumsy attempt at sexual liberation, which was painful and led me to embark on a committed journey of self care and spiritual enquiry, two integral paths I wanted to embark on when I left London. There's dick pics, google translate screenshots, flowers and snapshots of my baby nephew and ex husband, amongst the shoal of collated images. 

The series of works that have been the precursor to восем acht ocho have charted me slowly stripping away all the artiface and showmanship I normally use to conceal myself. Now in its last conception I am pretty much naked, nothing is edited or censored (save one drawing).

Once I have finished distributing the publication I will approach 88 venues of varying type (from kebab house, to flower shop, to gallery, to music venue) to hold 1x original drawing for the duration of 88 days, and as this happens I will make a map

Trajectory:

  • August - 2nd November 2018 - creation of 88x drawings and 8x songs.
  • 2nd November 2018 - 3x copies printed / album finished and uploaded.
  • 3-4th November 2018 - 3x copies distributed in Turin, Italy.
  • 4th November - 30th December 2018 - 85x copies printed and distributed throughout Berlin and to any overseas backers (11x per week roughly) // rehearse live show of album // approach and secure 88x venues to hold drawings, create map on website which will be updated live with locations.
  • 1st December 2018 - album and pdf of publication will be made publicly available.

Outcome

    In January 2019 I aim to premiere my live show in a few smaller venues in Berlin and to secure a space for a short run exhibition, where I will use the drawings to create an installation of the project and as a setting to hold a live show. During the exhibition and beyond its ending I will sell the 88x drawings online and at the exhibition space for €88 each.

    Incentives for backers

    • 0-20€ first dibs on original drawings - catalogue sent by email, optional updates on project are also available via mailing list.
    • 20-50€ (as above) + pdf copy of publication and exclusive link to album sent 8th November 2018.
    • 50€ + (as above, if desired) + 1x copy of gift wrapped print publication, sent to their address. 

    Thanks for reading, thank you for your support if you have chosen to give it and if not: because you have little or no means, I understand because I'm in the same boat.
story_txt:
I will start with a pulled reference:Self-realization and neuroticismAn innate need for self-realization leads people to explore and integrate these disowned parts of themselves. This natural process is called individuation, or the process of becoming an individual.According to Jung, self-realization is attained through individuation. His is an adult psychology, divided into two distinct tiers. In the first half of our lives, we separate from humanity. We attempt to create our own identities (“I”, “myself”). This is why there is such a need for young men to be destructive, and can be expressed as animosity from teens directed at their parents. Jung also said we have a sort of "second puberty" that occurs between ages 35 and 40: outlook shifts from emphasis on materialism, sexuality, and having children to concerns about community and spirituality.In the second half of our lives, humans reunite with the human race. They become part of the collective once again. This is when adults start to contribute to humanity (volunteer time, build, garden, create art, etc.) rather than destroy. They are also more likely to pay attention to their unconscious and conscious feelings. Young men rarely say "I feel angry" or "I feel sad." This is because they have not yet rejoined the human collective experience, commonly reestablished in their older, wiser years, according to Jung. A common theme is for young rebels to "search" for their true selves and realize that a contribution to humanity is essentially a necessity for a whole self.Jung proposes that the ultimate goal of the collective unconscious and self-realization is to pull us to the highest experience. This, of course, is spiritual.If a person does not proceed toward self-knowledge, neurotic symptoms may arise. Symptoms are widely defined, including, for instance, phobias, psychosis, and depression.(Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytical_psycho...)Hello,My name is Felice Zhukov.You might not know me, but then again you might know me, or you might read my blog, or you might have encountered my art before.There’s many variables here, lets just press on. I am an artist, this is what I do: My website.https://felicezhukov.net Instagram (specific platform only performances on here - though take heed I don’t use instagram at the moment and haven’t done for months)https://www.instagram.com/felicezhukov/ Soundcloud (my first tentative steps into working with sound, now though I know what a bar is so the album is a little more advanced).https://soundcloud.com/fep-2 These are all documents of my own process of individuation, which I refashion into the art I make. THE PROJECT I’m currently in the final stages of producing a 88 page guerilla publication and 8 track album dedicated to my ex husband, the amount asked for is far below what the real costs are, instead it is in keeping with the name of the project:  (+8% charge this site will take):восем = 8 acht = 8 ocho = 8,Those costs are for the last 3 months of production, including materials (paper, pens, paint, music gear), studio rent and time incurred from early planning to its distribution, in the coming months.As an example, photocopying alone will cost in excess of €200 as I am copying 88 x 88 pages (equalling 7,744) then individually hand binding and wrapping each copy  and depositing a link inside the parcel that will go through to a private page on my soundcloud, where you will be able to download and play the album. 8 is infinity turned on its axis, originally inspired by a hip hop lyric and then cemented by a small sojourn through numerology, 3 8’s because everything I do seems to be guided by the rule of 3.Infinity is forgiving as it presents the eternal, which nullifies the anxiety of small contrivances such as difficulties that present themselves in your life, when everything is framed in the vast eternal space nothing is quite so important. So despite the content of the publication and the album being so emotional and personal to me, its inception and creation have been undertaken with the understanding that it is one story among the many. The album takes it cues from a variation of musical influences mostly centred in the contemporary electronic scene, but inter splices distorted and layered vocals with a vein of absurdism and tragedy. Each song targets a moment in the relationship I had with my ex husband, whether it be our wedding, somewhere we lived or a holiday in Thailand. It has been created as a gift for him, as he has supported and looked after me even after the dissolution of our relationship.The publication consists of a set of photographs lifted from my iPhone and then drawn, these were not originally taken for the purpose of using them as art and therefore act to reveal my life through the images I received and recorded from March - August 2018, this period is when I moved from the London, my home of 10+ years to Berlin. As an ensemble they depict my brief and clumsy attempt at sexual liberation, which was painful and led me to embark on a committed journey of self care and spiritual enquiry, two integral paths I wanted to embark on when I left London. There's dick pics, google translate screenshots, flowers and snapshots of my baby nephew and ex husband, amongst the shoal of collated images. The series of works that have been the precursor to восем acht ocho have charted me slowly stripping away all the artiface and showmanship I normally use to conceal myself. Now in its last conception I am pretty much naked, nothing is edited or censored (save one drawing).Once I have finished distributing the publication I will approach 88 venues of varying type (from kebab house, to flower shop, to gallery, to music venue) to hold 1x original drawing for the duration of 88 days, and as this happens I will make a mapTrajectory:
August - 2nd November 2018 - creation of 88x drawings and 8x songs.
2nd November 2018 - 3x copies printed / album finished and uploaded.
3-4th November 2018 - 3x copies distributed in Turin, Italy.
4th November - 30th December 2018 - 85x copies printed and distributed throughout Berlin and to any overseas backers (11x per week roughly) // rehearse live show of album // approach and secure 88x venues to hold drawings, create map on website which will be updated live with locations.
1st December 2018 - album and pdf of publication will be made publicly available.
OutcomeIn January 2019 I aim to premiere my live show in a few smaller venues in Berlin and to secure a space for a short run exhibition, where I will use the drawings to create an installation of the project and as a setting to hold a live show. During the exhibition and beyond its ending I will sell the 88x drawings online and at the exhibition space for €88 each.Incentives for backers
0-20€ first dibs on original drawings - catalogue sent by email, optional updates on project are also available via mailing list.
20-50€ (as above) + pdf copy of publication and exclusive link to album sent 8th November 2018.
50€ + (as above, if desired) + 1x copy of gift wrapped print publication, sent to their address. 
Thanks for reading, thank you for your support if you have chosen to give it and if not: because you have little or no means, I understand because I'm in the same boat.

story:
Hi everyone! 

My name is Ivy.
I'm the creator, publisher, and the manufacturer of - The Wheel Of Fortune Tarot Deck  using the latest printing techniques which are currently not widespread.

  • Brass Gold, Blue Gold and Black Gold foil for the cards and box among many others you have never dreamed of.

  • Water Proof Plastic Cards for the mini deck for durability and a matte-texture for a more premium feel.

  • Skin-Like Texture Paper for the box which is totally matte and perfectly highlights the brass gold foil.

Many people are not aware of the vast array of printing methods that are available when it comes to printing tarot cards, and including other card games 

These include:

  • different color options for the gold foil printing.
  • different box material options.
  • different card stock options.

Based on the amount of remarkable and favorable comments I received on my successful Kickstarter campaign for - The Wheel Of Fortune Tarot deck; this has prompted me to launch this Indiegogo campaign. I have received so many email inquiries from my Kickstarter backers who loved the design and the printing quality of my Tarot deck so much, and are very interested in my printing work. I have also received so many E-mails from people who also want to buy my decks.

To know more about the different printing skills, please visit our website, or our Facebook, or   our Alibaba Shop under the company name of  

Shenzhen XM Playing Cards Co., Ltd.  &   

Shenzhen The Wheel Of Fortune Spiritual Art Creation Co., Ltd. 

  • Facebook: @woftarot
  • https://wheeloffortunetarot.en.alibaba.com
  • https://xmplayingcards.en.alibaba.com 

Below are the great pictures featuring both the standard and mini decks, both printed with the new foil colors printing skills. I hope that all of you Indiogogo backers and audiences will find - The Wheel Of Fortune Tarot card decks very interesting and appealing for you to support us with your pledges and make our campaign here also a successful one.

Thanks to you all!

Standard Deck:

1.)  Cards Size: 70x120mm,  78 cards per deck

2.)  Material: high quality 350 gsm art paper card stock

3.)  Printing: CMYK Printing +black gold foil printing for the front, Single black Printing +brass gold foil printing for the back

4.) Box: flip cover box made from smooth black paper with skin-like texture + 1200 gsm cardboard+brass gold foil printing for inside and outside the box

5.) Foil edges: STANDARD DECK" with 2 advance printing options:

                 A - Cards with Brass gold foil edges.

                 B - Cards with Holographic black foil edges

Mini Deck:

 1.)   Cards Size: 56x96mm, 78 cards per deck

2.)   Material: high quality eco-friendly 0.3mm white plastic card stock, water-proof, washable

3.)   Printing: CMYK Printing +black gold foil printing for the front, Blue gold foil printing for the back

4.) Box: book-shaped box with magnet click close made from smooth white paper with skin-like texture (paper feels like skin) + 1200 gsm cardboard+brass gold foil printing for inside and outside the box

 
 

 

The Wheel Of Fortune Tarot deck has incorporated the hearts and minds of many tarot card designers and authors I have met over my long career as a tarot card printer and printing manufacturer. 

 

They have been various people, such as doctors, housewives, card readers and filmmakers who have so many special feelings, unique understanding, passion and love for tarot art. 

We have created a strong business relationship and also a close friendship with each other, combining our creative ideas to produce custom tarot deck orders. The biggest highlight of my job is when a customer receives their custom tarot deck and is completely satisfied with every little detail.

The Wheel Of Fortune Tarot deck comes from my dream journey of making my own tarot deck. I have been very passionate about this idea for a long time and I have always dreamed of how it would look. This deck has been inspired by the traditional Rider-Waite tarot deck and consists of 78 beautiful hand-drawn oil paintings for the cards. This is the culmination of an emotional journey for me.

I need to express my appreciation and gratitude to our artist Miss Ganianrong for her beautiful oil paintings which express our ideas of optimism, confidence, courage， and love. She worked diligently for 8 long months from March to October 2018 to hand paint all 78 images. The design is ready and we are prepared for the printing.

The deck is also influenced by my reading of the book"Personal Renewal", by John William Gardner, Which I also quoted as part of the printing for both of the box designs.  

May I share the quote with you from the book: 

 

The Meaning Of Life 

Meaning is not something you stumble across, like the answer to a riddle or the prize in a treasure hunt.

Meaning is something you build into your life.

You build it out of your own past,

out of your affections and loyalties,

out of the experience of humankind as it is passed on to you,

out of your own talent and understanding,

out of the things you believe in,

out of the things and people you love,

out of the values for which you are willing to sacrifice something.

The ingredients are there. You are the only one who can put them together into that unique pattern that will be your life. Let it be a life that has dignity and meaning for you. If it does, then the particular balance of success or failure is of less account.

-"Personal Renewal", by John William Gardner

 

I know nothing great is accomplished alone, so that’s why I continue to need and highly appreciate your support in order to bring this project to life.

At this point, I wish to take this opportunity to thank all of my friends and customers along with my career and share my experience and encouragement to those who want to create their own custom tarot cards and run a business by infusing my ideas into The Wheel of Fortune Tarot Deck.

Thank you so much for your support!

The Wheel Of Fortune

 

The Fool

 

Strength

 

The Hermit

 

The World

The Wheel Of Fortune

The World

story:
Acrylic Warrior

Mental health for Veterans is an issue that the US has been dealing with for a long time, but it’s affecting more Americans than ever. Veterans today are lacking effective resources and oftentimes take a turn for the worst and never recover.

Christian, the main subject of this project, has experienced combat warfare in Iraq and has seen first hand what the aftermath of war looks like. When returning from war, he was affected from PTSD, and upon trying to recover, found frustration, helplessness, until he began to paint. This therapy was found in an usual place for Christian, but it was the turning point for his recovery. Artwork was a way to express feelings and emotions in a unique way, and since finding success, he has put himself out there to help other Vets treat their PTSD with art.

Mental health is more relevant today than it’s ever been. With the suicide rates at an all-time high, we need to address solutions to help save the people we value most. Military Veterans have risked their lives, and are unable to recover. Therapy is not always easily accessible, and people might be waiting to “snap out of it” for their whole life. Christian will be joined by other Veterans who have first hand experience with PTSD who can relate deeply to the topic, and share knowledge.

We are here to bring light on a major issue, but to encourage anybody who has suffered from PTSD, or Depression, to not lose hope, and find the power within to give new forms of therapy a chance when nothing else works. 

A Message From The Artist

Hello! My name is Christian. Thirteen years ago after returning from Iraq, I found therapy through painting. Art has helped me work through my challenges with PTSD. After my newfound love of art, I became an advocate for mental wellness in the Veteran community. This year, I made a huge breakthrough using the non-profit Give An Hour and am devoted to helping spread the word. 

Many Veterans come home from war and have a difficult time adjusting to civilian life. We are expected to shed our anger, guilt and depression as if it were skin and step into a new body. Some adapt and overcome but some aren’t as fortunate. It is estimated that 22 Veterans commit suicide A DAY. Those are only the numbers that go reported. I believe it’s higher than that. It’s never too late. Make the phone call, go for a walk, start saying yes to all and any opportunities. Do ANYTHING but stop fighting. You have so much to offer whether you believe it or not. I could’ve stayed on the couch 13 years ago and closed myself off to the world. I would’ve known exactly how my life would’ve ended. Instead, I made the choice to keep fighting.

 

Enlist Yourself...

No, we aren't asking you to sign on any dotted lines (many of us have done that already). By signing up, you are part of a team. A movement that combats Veteran-suicide with peace, love and happiness through creativity. We are seeking $120,000 to fund this project. The budget will cover the film crew, project coordinator, production artist, marketing, public relations, and travel expenses.

  • Project Artist $20,000
  • Project Manager $10,000
  • Film Crew $76,000 (Note: They not only produce the documentary, but also handle post production as well, i.e. marketing, website, etc.)
  • Travel/Shipping Expenses $14,000

If we don't meet our goal, we will revisit our plan and discuss cheaper alternatives. We will take what we do raise and still make this campaign happen but on a smaller scale.

Unique perks of this project will include:

  • A Digital Presale of the Acrylic Warfare documentary
  • Limited Edition Canvas Giclée (signed and numbered)
  • Limited Edition 11x17 Posters (signed and numbered)
  • Campaign T-Shirt
  • Supporter, Associate & Executive Producer credit opportunities

The Impact

Inspiration is key. Through myself and a different guest speaker in each city, my vision is to inspire others. I'll never forget the night I went to my first art show. I found some of the most beautiful, creepiest, powerful paintings that sparked something inside of me. The next day, I felt like a little kid showing my parents pictures from the show. Art saves. It saved me and it continues to save many others every day. I understand that art isn't the answer for everyone, but my story is living proof that life is still worth fighting for. 

 

Key Creative Personnel

Christian Gabriel, Main Subject 

Christian is the Veteran and Painter. Since treating himself, he has become a artist in Portland, OR where he creates and sells his work. He also works with Veterans who have similar issues and associates himself close to organizations that share the same vision of helping Vets.

Alex Moan, Director/Cinematographer

Alex is a Portland based filmmaker who has enhanced businesses strategies through storytelling, visual strategies, and targeted Documentaries. Aside from being a filmmaker, he is a photographer, and an owner/partner at Black Bulb Creative.

Luke Thompson, Producer/Cinematographer

Luke is a photographer turned filmmaker and is also a owner/partner at Black Bulb Creative. He is known to keep structure within Black Bulb and develops creative strategies for all projects. His visual passion expands past film, where he designs graphics for clothing in the Portland area.

Tom Sollitt, Project Manager

Tom is a Brand Development Consultant based in Portland, Oregon. He is focused on moving past quantitative and qualitative data. Through observation and immersion he learns and understands important aspects about a subject that cannot be measured.

 

Risks & Challenges

This project is about supporting the mental wellness of our Veterans. This is a journey. We are not measuring our success by anything other than spreading awareness and reaching Veterans and their families. We will reach out to all Veteran-related clubs and businesses in each of the cities we tour. We will also engage through our social media presence to invite attendees to our art shows.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Follow @official_ChristianGabriel on Instagram for updates
  • Buddy Check. Share knowledge of the Veterans Crisis Line 1-800-273-8255
  • Visit and share www.giveanhour.org with Veterans

story:
“It’s our memories that make us interesting; stories of amazing journeys, nights out seeing something new, cultural, exciting, provocative, or even life-changing. These were my emotions after seeing Giles Walkers’ The Last Supper at The London Science Museum. I want you to understand those feelings when you come to experience MONSTER.” - Ben Oakley.

Giles Walker is no stranger to producing the full on ‘art experience’. Over 30 years ago he joined the guerrilla art group, Mutoid Waste Company. With this collective of artists, he traveled all over Europe living and creating art experiences that are still spoken about with great enthusiasm today. With Giles Walker’s current work, he continues to deliver intense, physical, sculpture. Emotions are acted out in the movement of figures and everyday objects using simple mechanisms. Kinetic sculpture, as with the choreography of dance, or physical theatre, can also strive to find a ‘poetry in motion’ and this has become the main drive behind his work.

Using animatronics, sound, and light to create a tightly synchronized piece of art, MONSTER is sure to provoke a raw emotional response and leave the viewer with an experience they will never forget. 

The installation will be set in an atmospheric Georgian Warehouse on the Thames. You will not view this installation passively from afar...you will be in it and immediately surrounded by animatronic figures (some 4.5m tall) as they interact between themselves and with you. Different perspectives will be experienced from this piece of sculpture depending on where you are, and when, allowing the audience a fresh experience each time they visit. 

“Giles Walker is a master sculptor and a genius”- Ken Russell, The Times 

What We Need & What You Get

Giles Walker & the Ben Oakley Gallery have been in pre-production on MONSTER for around 14 months already, there have been numerous studio and location visits, midnight phone calls, the odd pint, emails galore, design drawings, meetings, models made, creative planning and fine-tuning. All this preparation leaves us truly confident that we can deliver a memorable art experience to everyone who visits the MONSTER exhibition. 

The same attention to detail has been given in developing some interesting and creative ideas to offer as our exclusive Indiegogo crowdfunding perks/rewards.

Work on the show has already begun. The concept behind the show is pretty much locked down and Giles has already begun fabricating some of the animatronic characters that will play a part in this huge kinetic sculpture. A singer has been found and has begun recording vocals for one of these characters to sing. Dialogue is being written. Trees have been felled and carved for the larger sculptures and our various storage units are beginning to fill up with a collection of materials needed. We are on it.

We have set our campaign target at just £38,000. This is the minimum amount we believe is needed to make this project possible. Half of this amount will pay for the materials required in the build of this installation. Motors, steel, bearings, lighting, digital components, such as the DMX PCB's, cabling, fiberglass, scaffolding, are all essential for the fabrication of this piece. Giles’s many years of experience has taught him how to be imaginative in order to keep costs down (he is originally a scrap artist after all) but, ultimately, the work must be made to a high standard and short cuts can often backfire badly in the world of kinetics! 

Most importantly, at this early stage, in order for Giles to continue with the build and stick to the schedule, we need to raise £6,000 so that he can concentrate full time on the essential design & fabrication. This amount will allow him a few months without other distractions and is based on his minimum studio and living costs. 

The Georgian Warehouse where we plan to exhibit the show will cost over £6,000 This is for the 25 days of MONSTER pre-build, technical checks, exhibition days & dismantle.

An additional £4,000 is needed for staffing, production & PR for the next 7 months until installment.

Combined, we have over 50 years of experience in the creative art world industry. Ben Oakley Gallery has been in operation for ten years and has curated over 100 Exhibitions in London and Europe. It is well experienced in putting on large public events. Giles Walker has traveled with his work all over the world and exhibited it in a huge variety of different venues and environments. With the funds requested, we can do this.

For additional insight into Giles Walker’s work please check out his website wwww.gileswalker.org to view a short film of his phenomenal piece ‘The Last Supper’, recently exhibited in The London Science Museum. You will instantly get a clear picture in your mind of the exquisite finish, style & quality he incorporates into his work and how he uses it to build upon a strong and provocative concept.

A similar approach to his work will, of course, be taken as he launches into his most ambitious installation to date, MONSTER. A unique art experience we feel you’ll happily carry with you for a very long time. It can’t happen without you. Thank you.

The Impact

 With MONSTER my aim is to present a difficult and broad concept in the most visual way possible. However, I won't stop there because I will use sound and movement in a way that will make you feel this sculpture physically as well.

My intention is that MONSTER will appeal to people of all ages. I hope that everyone will experience something personal as well as collective from their visit. I want to leave people inspired and satisfied but also with the feeling that they missed something…so they come back again!"  -

Giles Walker

Risks & Challenges

We have a proven track record of working successfully on many different projects and that does help with our confidence that MONSTER will be a show like no other. 

Our major challenge is to raise enough funds so we can secure the materials for fabrication, the venue/location, and buy some focussed creative time within our set timetable. 

We think that the perks/rewards on offer are interesting, of worth, and reflect the nature of the project as a whole. We sincerely hope that you can see the value in backing/investing in our Monster Campaign and find a perk that suits you. 

We fully understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially but wish that you share our Indiegogo MONSTER campaign to some or all of your contacts and we will look forward to seeing you at the secret warehouse location in September 2019. Thank you for A special thanks to Wieden & Kennedy & Thames Side Print Studios.
story_txt:

story:
Short Summary

We are a camp of artists, chefs, caterers, DJs and mixologists who have come together to create all the best of Fire and Ice for Burning Flipside. We will bring the artistic talents we have exhibited around the world to sculpt ice in performance for our fellow Flipizens. We will create a DJ stand out of Ice for our talented DJs to spin their fine tunes on. Our fabulous shot ladies will pour elixers over special Ice shot slides to the delight of all and we will provide our World Famous Flamethrower Pizza for our guests enjoyment.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to provide ice blocks for sculptures and gas for the freezer truck to keep our sculpting medium sub zero until performance time. We also hope to help our fellow campmate fund Spindra which she has invested so much already to make happen for Flipside (see here: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/spindra-momm... ) By helping to fund these items you may enjoy perks ranging from our eternal gratitude to a steak dinner cooked by our award winning Chef/Sculptor in the company of the Fire and Ice camp to even having your OWN shot slide in camp. This year our camp is also bringing Spindra installation, a brewmaster and home liquor maker, WHIMSY - our art installation using ALL of the Flipside ticket envelopes and many more art installations for your enjoyment. See our website to view some of the amazing works created by our Master Ice Artist.  www.wickedice.com   And please like our Facebook page for more details - https://www.facebook.com/WickedIceAustin

The Impact

This is our third year for Fire and Ice camp at Burning Flipside and we intend to be a positive addition to the community by exhibiting the burning principles and radically adding to the event. Your support will help us attain these goals. 
Also, any extra monies raised will go towards our new "Fire and Ice Art Grant". Our goal is to offer money to artists in our community to continue working in their mediums while providing NEW and exciting art for our local burns.

Risks & Challenges

Because we are a LARGE camp who really brings it, we are already stretched thin bringing our bar, staging, art installations and so much more. We love bringing flamethrower pizzas every year and we gift them in the evening when people need food the most. Our ice is a one of a kind experience and without the help of our community, we may struggle to provide the simple things we are known for. Although we know there are other art projects out there, we fully intend on helping our fellow artists by creating a yearly art grant to help cover their expenditures. Help us help keep art in our community!

Other Ways You Can Help

Contribute if you can and receive one of our cool perks. If you are unable to contribute, please help let others know about our campaign, or just share a positive thought with some one while thinking of us. Enrich your life in unexpected ways and share your experiences. <3 the entire Fire and Ice Family 2015.
